most species are hermaphrodites -- a single animal can produce both eggs and sperm , meaning it can fertilize its own egg , not needing a mate .	what gender are most species of ctenophores ?	most species are hermaphrodites -- a single animal can produce both eggs and sperm
the young are generally planktonic and in most species look like miniature cydippids , gradually changing into their adult shapes as they grow .	what do young ctenophores generaly look like ?	the young are generally planktonic and in most species look like miniature cydippids
in at least some species , juveniles are capable of reproduction before reaching the adult size and shape .	are juiveniles capable of reproduction ?	juveniles are capable of reproduction before reaching the adult size and shape
most species are hermaphrodites -- a single animal can produce both eggs and sperm , meaning it can fertilize its own egg , not needing a mate .	what is unique about a hermaphrodite ?	most species are hermaphrodites -- a single animal can produce both eggs and sperm
some are simultaneous hermaphrodites , which can produce both eggs and sperm at the same time .	what can a simultaneous hermaphrodite do ?	which can produce both eggs and sperm at the same time
others are sequential hermaphrodites , in which the eggs and sperm mature at different times .	what type of hermaphrodite produces egg and sperm at different times ?	in which the eggs and sperm mature at different times
fertilization is generally external , although platyctenids ' eggs are fertilized inside their parents ' bodies and kept there until they hatch .	which species eggs are fertilized and kept inside the parents body until hatched ?	although platyctenids ' eggs are fertilized inside their parents ' bodies and kept there until they hatch
the combination of hermaphroditism and early reproduction enables small populations to grow at an explosive rate .	what causes the population of ctenophora to grow at an explosive rate ?	the combination of hermaphroditism and early reproduction enables small populations to grow at an explosive rate

the exceptions are the beroids , whose young are miniature beroids with large mouths and no tentacles , and the platyctenids , whose young live as cydippid-like plankton until they reach near-adult size , but then sink to the bottom and rapidly metamorphose into the adult form .	which group has young that are born with no tentacles and a large mouth ?	whose young live as cydippid-like plankton until they reach near-adult size
one ctenophore , mnemiopsis , has accidentally been introduced into the black sea , where it is blamed for causing fish stocks to collapse by eating both fish larvae and organisms that would otherwise have fed the fish .	what sea were ctenophores accidently introduced ?	where it is blamed for causing fish stocks to collapse by eating both fish larvae and organisms that would otherwise have fed the fish

a recent molecular phylogenetics analysis concluded that the common ancestor of all modern ctenophores was cydippid-like , and that all the modern groups appeared relatively recently , probably after the cretaceous -- paleogene extinction event 66 million years ago .	when did the cretaceous-paleogene extinction happen ?	a recent molecular phylogenetics analysis concluded that the common ancestor of all modern ctenophores was cydippid-like
evidence accumulating since the 1980s indicates that the `` cydippids '' are not monophyletic , in other words do not include all and only the descendants of a single common ancestor , because all the other traditional ctenophore groups are descendants of various cydippids .	evidence indicates that cydippids are not what ?	evidence accumulating since the 1980s indicates that the `` cydippids '' are not monophyletic
despite their soft , gelatinous bodies , fossils thought to represent ctenophores , apparently with no tentacles but many more comb-rows than modern forms , have been found in lagerstätten as far back as the early cambrian , about 515 million years ago .	how old are the fossils found that represent ctenophhores ?	apparently with no tentacles but many more comb-rows than modern forms

ctenophores form an animal phylum that is more complex than sponges , about as complex as cnidarians -lrb- jellyfish , sea anemones , etc. -rrb- , and less complex than bilaterians -lrb- which include almost all other animals -rrb- .	jellyfish ans sea anemones belong to what phylum ?	and less complex than bilaterians -lrb- which include almost all other animals -rrb-
ctenophores are distinguished from all other animals by having colloblasts , which are sticky and adhere to prey , although a few ctenophore species lack them .	what makes ctenophores different from all other animals ?	ctenophores are distinguished from all other animals by having colloblasts

unlike sponges , both ctenophores and cnidarians have : cells bound by inter-cell connections and carpet-like basement membranes ; muscles ; nervous systems ; and some have sensory organs .	which two groups have cells bound by inter-cell connections and membranes , muscles , a nervous system and sensory organs ?	both ctenophores and cnidarians have : cells bound by inter-cell connections and carpet-like basement membranes
ctenophores form an animal phylum that is more complex than sponges , about as complex as cnidarians -lrb- jellyfish , sea anemones , etc. -rrb- , and less complex than bilaterians -lrb- which include almost all other animals -rrb- .	ctenophores are less complex than what other group ?	and less complex than bilaterians -lrb- which include almost all other animals -rrb-
like sponges and cnidarians , ctenophores have two main layers of cells that sandwich a middle layer of jelly-like material , which is called the mesoglea in cnidarians and ctenophores ; more complex animals have three main cell layers and no intermediate jelly-like layer .	what is the jelly-like susbtance called ?	ctenophores have two main layers of cells that sandwich a middle layer of jelly-like material
hence ctenophores and cnidarians have traditionally been labelled diploblastic , along with sponges .	ctenophores and cnidarians are classified as what ?	hence ctenophores and cnidarians have traditionally been labelled diploblastic
like sponges and cnidarians , ctenophores have two main layers of cells that sandwich a middle layer of jelly-like material , which is called the mesoglea in cnidarians and ctenophores ; more complex animals have three main cell layers and no intermediate jelly-like layer .	which group has two layers of cells with a middle layer of mesoglea ?	ctenophores have two main layers of cells that sandwich a middle layer of jelly-like material
hence ctenophores and cnidarians have traditionally been labelled diploblastic , along with sponges .	ctenophores , cnidarians and what other group are labelled diploblastic ?	hence ctenophores and cnidarians have traditionally been labelled diploblastic
ranging from about 1 millimeter -lrb- 0.039 in -rrb- to 1.5 meters -lrb- 4.9 ft -rrb- in size , ctenophores are the largest non-colonial animals that use cilia -lrb- `` hairs '' -rrb- as their main method of locomotion .	what are the hairs on ctenophores called ?	ctenophores are the largest non-colonial animals that use cilia -lrb- `` hairs '' -rrb- as their main method of locomotion
ranging from about 1 millimeter -lrb- 0.039 in -rrb- to 1.5 meters -lrb- 4.9 ft -rrb- in size , ctenophores are the largest non-colonial animals that use cilia -lrb- `` hairs '' -rrb- as their main method of locomotion .	what are cilia used for ?	ctenophores are the largest non-colonial animals that use cilia -lrb- `` hairs '' -rrb- as their main method of locomotion
most species have eight strips , called comb rows , that run the length of their bodies and bear comb-like bands of cilia , called `` ctenes , '' stacked along the comb rows so that when the cilia beat , those of each comb touch the comb below .	comb like bands of cilia are called what ?	that run the length of their bodies and bear comb-like bands of cilia
the name `` ctenophora '' means `` comb-bearing '' , from the greek κτείς -lrb- stem-form κτεν - -rrb- meaning `` comb '' and the greek suffix - φορος meaning `` carrying '' .	what does ctenophore mean in greek ?	from the greek κτείς -lrb- stem-form κτεν - -rrb- meaning `` comb '' and the greek suffix - φορος meaning `` carrying ''
at least two textbooks base their descriptions of ctenophores on the cydippid pleurobrachia .	which cidippid is used as a description on ctenophores in most textbooks ?	at least two textbooks base their descriptions of ctenophores on the cydippid pleurobrachia
coastal species need to be tough enough to withstand waves and swirling sediment particles , while some oceanic species are so fragile that it is very difficult to capture them intact for study .	which group of ctenophore are are hardest to study ?	while some oceanic species are so fragile that it is very difficult to capture them intact for study
coastal species need to be tough enough to withstand waves and swirling sediment particles , while some oceanic species are so fragile that it is very difficult to capture them intact for study .	why are coastal species tough ?	while some oceanic species are so fragile that it is very difficult to capture them intact for study
hence most attention has until recently concentrated on three coastal genera -- pleurobrachia , beroe and mnemiopsis .	which ctenophora have been studies the most ?	hence most attention has until recently concentrated on three coastal genera -- pleurobrachia
the inner surface of the cavity is lined with an epithelium , the gastrodermis .	the inside of a ctenophore is lined with what ?	the inner surface of the cavity is lined with an epithelium
the nearer side is composed of tall nutritive cells that store nutrients in vacuoles -lrb- internal compartments -rrb- , germ cells that produce eggs or sperm , and photocytes that produce bioluminescence .	what do photocytes produce ?	the nearer side is composed of tall nutritive cells that store nutrients in vacuoles -lrb- internal compartments -rrb-
the internal cavity forms : a mouth that can usually be closed by muscles ; a pharynx -lrb- `` throat '' -rrb- ; a wider area in the center that acts as a stomach ; and a system of internal canals .	what is the throat called ?	the internal cavity forms : a mouth that can usually be closed by muscles
the internal cavity forms : a mouth that can usually be closed by muscles ; a pharynx -lrb- `` throat '' -rrb- ; a wider area in the center that acts as a stomach ; and a system of internal canals .	what does the internal cavity contain ?	the internal cavity forms : a mouth that can usually be closed by muscles
these branch through the mesoglea to the most active parts of the animal : the mouth and pharynx ; the roots of the tentacles , if present ; all along the underside of each comb row ; and four branches round the sensory complex at the far end from the mouth -- two of these four branches terminate in anal pores .	what are the most active parts of ctenophora ?	and four branches round the sensory complex at the far end from the mouth -- two of these four branches terminate in anal pores
the outer surface bears usually eight comb rows , called swimming-plates , which are used for swimming .	what are the eight comb rows on the outer surface called ?	the outer surface bears usually eight comb rows
the `` combs '' -lrb- also called `` ctenes '' or `` comb plates '' -rrb- run across each row , and each consists of thousands of unusually long cilia , up to 2 millimeters -lrb- 0.079 in -rrb- .	combs are called what ?	the `` combs '' -lrb- also called `` ctenes '' or `` comb plates '' -rrb- run across each row
unlike conventional cilia and flagella , which has a filament structure arranged in a 9 + 2 pattern , these cilia are arranged in a 9 + 3 pattern , where the extra compact filament is suspected to have a supporting function .	what does the 9 +3 pattern of cilia thought to do ?	where the extra compact filament is suspected to have a supporting function
hence ctenophores usually swim in the direction in which the mouth is pointing , unlike jellyfish .	what direction do ctenophore swim ?	hence ctenophores usually swim in the direction in which the mouth is pointing
the `` combs '' -lrb- also called `` ctenes '' or `` comb plates '' -rrb- run across each row , and each consists of thousands of unusually long cilia , up to 2 millimeters -lrb- 0.079 in -rrb- .	cilia can g ow up too what length ?	the `` combs '' -lrb- also called `` ctenes '' or `` comb plates '' -rrb- run across each row
it is uncertain how ctenophores control their buoyancy , but experiments have shown that some species rely on osmotic pressure to adapt to water of different densities .	how do ctenophores control buoyancy ?	but experiments have shown that some species rely on osmotic pressure to adapt to water of different densities
if they enter less dense brackish water , the ciliary rosettes in the body cavity may pump this into the mesoglea to increase its bulk and decrease its density , to avoid sinking .	ciliary rosettes pump water into what to control buoyancy ?	the ciliary rosettes in the body cavity may pump this into the mesoglea to increase its bulk and decrease its density
if they enter less dense brackish water , the ciliary rosettes in the body cavity may pump this into the mesoglea to increase its bulk and decrease its density , to avoid sinking .	what does pumping water into the mesoglea do ?	the ciliary rosettes in the body cavity may pump this into the mesoglea to increase its bulk and decrease its density
conversely if they move from brackish to full-strength seawater , the rosettes may pump water out of the mesoglea to reduce its volume and increase its density .	what does the ciliary rosettes do to decease bulk and increase density ?	the rosettes may pump water out of the mesoglea to reduce its volume and increase its density
the largest single sensory feature is the aboral organ -lrb- at the opposite end from the mouth -rrb- .	what is the largest sensory feature of the ctenophora ?	the largest single sensory feature is the aboral organ -lrb- at the opposite end from the mouth -rrb-
the largest single sensory feature is the aboral organ -lrb- at the opposite end from the mouth -rrb- .	where is the aboral organ located ?	the largest single sensory feature is the aboral organ -lrb- at the opposite end from the mouth -rrb-
the statocyst is protected by a transparent dome made of long , immobile cilia .	what protects the statocyst ?	the statocyst is protected by a transparent dome made of long
its main component is a statocyst , a balance sensor consisting of a statolith , a solid particle supported on four bundles of cilia , called `` balancers '' , that sense its orientation .	what is the main component of the aboral organ ?	a solid particle supported on four bundles of cilia
its main component is a statocyst , a balance sensor consisting of a statolith , a solid particle supported on four bundles of cilia , called `` balancers '' , that sense its orientation .	what is a statocyst ?	a solid particle supported on four bundles of cilia
cydippid ctenophores have bodies that are more or less rounded , sometimes nearly spherical and other times more cylindrical or egg-shaped ; the common coastal `` sea gooseberry , '' pleurobrachia , sometimes has an egg-shaped body with the mouth at the narrow end , although some individuals are more uniformly round .	what is the common coastal pleurobrachia called ?	sometimes nearly spherical and other times more cylindrical or egg-shaped
from opposite sides of the body extends a pair of long , slender tentacles , each housed in a sheath into which it can be withdrawn .	what does the pleurobrachia have on opposite sides of its body ?	each housed in a sheath into which it can be withdrawn
cydippid ctenophores have bodies that are more or less rounded , sometimes nearly spherical and other times more cylindrical or egg-shaped ; the common coastal `` sea gooseberry , '' pleurobrachia , sometimes has an egg-shaped body with the mouth at the narrow end , although some individuals are more uniformly round .	cydippid are typically what shape ?	sometimes nearly spherical and other times more cylindrical or egg-shaped
from opposite sides of the body extends a pair of long , slender tentacles , each housed in a sheath into which it can be withdrawn .	the long tentacles on the pleurbrachia are protected by what ?	from opposite sides of the body extends a pair of long
cydippid ctenophores have bodies that are more or less rounded , sometimes nearly spherical and other times more cylindrical or egg-shaped ; the common coastal `` sea gooseberry , '' pleurobrachia , sometimes has an egg-shaped body with the mouth at the narrow end , although some individuals are more uniformly round .	where is the mouth located on the pleuobrachia located ?	sometimes nearly spherical and other times more cylindrical or egg-shaped
the tentacles of cydippid ctenophores are typically fringed with tentilla -lrb- `` little tentacles '' -rrb- , although a few genera have simple tentacles without these sidebranches .	what are the tentacles of cydipped ctenophores are usually fringed with ?	the tentacles of cydippid ctenophores are typically fringed with tentilla -lrb- `` little tentacles '' -rrb-
colloblasts are specialized mushroom-shaped cells in the outer layer of the epidermis , and have three main components : a domed head with vesicles -lrb- chambers -rrb- that contain adhesive ; a stalk that anchors the cell in the lower layer of the epidermis or in the mesoglea ; and a spiral thread that coils round the stalk and is attached to the head and to the root of the stalk .	what are colloblasts ?	and a spiral thread that coils round the stalk and is attached to the head and to the root of the stalk
the tentilla of euplokamis differ significantly from those of other cydippids : they contain striated muscle , a cell type otherwise unknown in the phylum ctenophora ; and they are coiled when relaxed , while the tentilla of all other known ctenophores elongate when relaxed .	what makes the tentilla of euplokamis different from other cysippids ?	the tentilla of euplokamis differ significantly from those of other cydippids : they contain striated muscle
euplokamis ' tentilla have three types of movement that are used in capturing prey : they may flick out very quickly -lrb- in 40 to 60 milliseconds -rrb- ; they can wriggle , which may lure prey by behaving like small planktonic worms ; and they coil round prey .	how many types of movements do euplokamis tentilla have ?	euplokamis ' tentilla have three types of movement that are used in capturing prey : they may flick out very quickly -lrb- in 40 to 60 milliseconds -rrb-
euplokamis ' tentilla have three types of movement that are used in capturing prey : they may flick out very quickly -lrb- in 40 to 60 milliseconds -rrb- ; they can wriggle , which may lure prey by behaving like small planktonic worms ; and they coil round prey .	what does the euplokamis use the three types of movement for ?	euplokamis ' tentilla have three types of movement that are used in capturing prey : they may flick out very quickly -lrb- in 40 to 60 milliseconds -rrb-
there are eight rows of combs that run from near the mouth to the opposite end , and are spaced evenly round the body .	how many rows of combs are there ?	there are eight rows of combs that run from near the mouth to the opposite end
there are eight rows of combs that run from near the mouth to the opposite end , and are spaced evenly round the body .	where are the rows of combs located ?	there are eight rows of combs that run from near the mouth to the opposite end
there are eight rows of combs that run from near the mouth to the opposite end , and are spaced evenly round the body .	how are the combs spaced ?	there are eight rows of combs that run from near the mouth to the opposite end
from each balancer in the statocyst a ciliary groove runs out under the dome and then splits to connect with two adjacent comb rows , and in some species runs all the way along the comb rows .	what runs from the balancer in the statocyst to the comb rows ?	from each balancer in the statocyst a ciliary groove runs out under the dome and then splits to connect with two adjacent comb rows
the lobata have a pair of lobes , which are muscular , cuplike extensions of the body that project beyond the mouth .	what does the lobata have pair of ?	cuplike extensions of the body that project beyond the mouth
between the lobes on either side of the mouth , many species of lobates have four auricles , gelatinous projections edged with cilia that produce water currents that help direct microscopic prey toward the mouth .	what are auricles ?	gelatinous projections edged with cilia that produce water currents that help direct microscopic prey toward the mouth
between the lobes on either side of the mouth , many species of lobates have four auricles , gelatinous projections edged with cilia that produce water currents that help direct microscopic prey toward the mouth .	how many auricles do most species have ?	gelatinous projections edged with cilia that produce water currents that help direct microscopic prey toward the mouth
between the lobes on either side of the mouth , many species of lobates have four auricles , gelatinous projections edged with cilia that produce water currents that help direct microscopic prey toward the mouth .	what do the auricles do ?	gelatinous projections edged with cilia that produce water currents that help direct microscopic prey toward the mouth
this combination of structures enables lobates to feed continuously on suspended planktonic prey .	what do lobates feed on ?	this combination of structures enables lobates to feed continuously on suspended planktonic prey
members of the lobate genera bathocyroe and ocyropsis can escape from danger by clapping their lobes , so that the jet of expelled water drives them backwards very quickly .	what does the bathocyroe and ocyropsis do to escape danger ?	members of the lobate genera bathocyroe and ocyropsis can escape from danger by clapping their lobes
members of the lobate genera bathocyroe and ocyropsis can escape from danger by clapping their lobes , so that the jet of expelled water drives them backwards very quickly .	what happens when bathocyroe and ocyropsis clap their lobes together ?	members of the lobate genera bathocyroe and ocyropsis can escape from danger by clapping their lobes
unlike cydippids , the movements of lobates ' combs are coordinated by nerves rather than by water disturbances created by the cilia , yet combs on the same row beat in the same mexican wave style as the mechanically coordinated comb rows of cydippids and beroids .	the movements of the lobates combs are controlled by what ?	yet combs on the same row beat in the same mexican wave style as the mechanically coordinated comb rows of cydippids and beroids
unlike cydippids , the movements of lobates ' combs are coordinated by nerves rather than by water disturbances created by the cilia , yet combs on the same row beat in the same mexican wave style as the mechanically coordinated comb rows of cydippids and beroids .	cydippids combs are controlled by what ?	yet combs on the same row beat in the same mexican wave style as the mechanically coordinated comb rows of cydippids and beroids
the beroida , also known as nuda , have no feeding appendages , but their large pharynx , just inside the large mouth and filling most of the saclike body , bears `` macrocilia '' at the oral end .	beroida are known by what other name ?	just inside the large mouth and filling most of the saclike body
the beroida , also known as nuda , have no feeding appendages , but their large pharynx , just inside the large mouth and filling most of the saclike body , bears `` macrocilia '' at the oral end .	what group has no feeding appendages ?	just inside the large mouth and filling most of the saclike body
in front of the field of macrocilia , on the mouth `` lips '' in some species of beroe , is a pair of narrow strips of adhesive epithelial cells on the stomach wall that `` zip '' the mouth shut when the animal is not feeding , by forming intercellular connections with the opposite adhesive strip .	some species of beroe have a pair of strips of adhesive cells on the stomach wall .what does it do ?	is a pair of narrow strips of adhesive epithelial cells on the stomach wall that `` zip '' the mouth shut when the animal is not feeding

the beroida , also known as nuda , have no feeding appendages , but their large pharynx , just inside the large mouth and filling most of the saclike body , bears `` macrocilia '' at the oral end .	what does the beroida have instead of feeding appendages ?	just inside the large mouth and filling most of the saclike body
the cestida -lrb- `` belt animals '' -rrb- are ribbon-shaped planktonic animals , with the mouth and aboral organ aligned in the middle of opposite edges of the ribbon .	which species are ribbon-shaped planktonic animals ?	with the mouth and aboral organ aligned in the middle of opposite edges of the ribbon
there are two known species , with worldwide distribution in warm , and warm-temperate waters : cestum veneris -lrb- `` venus ' girdle '' -rrb- is among the largest ctenophores -- up to 1.5 meters -lrb- 4.9 ft -rrb- long , and can undulate slowly or quite rapidly .	what is the largest ctenophore ?	and warm-temperate waters : cestum veneris -lrb- `` venus ' girdle '' -rrb- is among the largest ctenophores -- up to 1
the cestida -lrb- `` belt animals '' -rrb- are ribbon-shaped planktonic animals , with the mouth and aboral organ aligned in the middle of opposite edges of the ribbon .	what are cestida called ?	with the mouth and aboral organ aligned in the middle of opposite edges of the ribbon
cestids can swim by undulating their bodies as well as by the beating of their comb-rows .	how do cestids swim ?	cestids can swim by undulating their bodies as well as by the beating of their comb-rows
velamen parallelum , which is typically less than 20 centimeters -lrb- 0.66 ft -rrb- long , can move much faster in what has been described as a `` darting motion '' .	which species moves by a darting motion ?	can move much faster in what has been described as a `` darting motion ''
most platyctenida have oval bodies that are flattened in the oral-aboral direction , with a pair of tentilla-bearing tentacles on the aboral surface .	what do most platyctenida have on their aboral surface ?	most platyctenida have oval bodies that are flattened in the oral-aboral direction
they cling to and creep on surfaces by everting the pharynx and using it as a muscular `` foot '' .	what do platyctenida use their pharynx for ?	they cling to and creep on surfaces by everting the pharynx and using it as a muscular `` foot ''
all but one of the known platyctenid species lack comb-rows .	what do all but one platycenida species lack ?	all but one of the known platyctenid species lack comb-rows
platyctenids are usually cryptically colored , live on rocks , algae , or the body surfaces of other invertebrates , and are often revealed by their long tentacles with many sidebranches , seen streaming off the back of the ctenophore into the current .	where do platycenida live ?	and are often revealed by their long tentacles with many sidebranches
the gonads are located in the parts of the internal canal network under the comb rows , and eggs and sperm are released via pores in the epidermis .	how are eggs and sperm released ?	the gonads are located in the parts of the internal canal network under the comb rows
fertilization is external in most species , but platyctenids use internal fertilization and keep the eggs in brood chambers until they hatch .	how do platyctenids reproduce ?	but platyctenids use internal fertilization and keep the eggs in brood chambers until they hatch
self-fertilization has occasionally been seen in species of the genus mnemiopsis , and it is thought that most of the hermaphroditic species are self-fertile .	what genus has self-fertilization been seen ?	self-fertilization has occasionally been seen in species of the genus mnemiopsis
the gonads are located in the parts of the internal canal network under the comb rows , and eggs and sperm are released via pores in the epidermis .	where are the gonads located ?	the gonads are located in the parts of the internal canal network under the comb rows
fertilization is external in most species , but platyctenids use internal fertilization and keep the eggs in brood chambers until they hatch .	is fertilization internal or exeternal in most species ?	but platyctenids use internal fertilization and keep the eggs in brood chambers until they hatch
in the genus beroe the juveniles , like the adults , lack tentacles and tentacle sheaths .	juvenile and adult beroe lack what ?	lack tentacles and tentacle sheaths
in some groups , such as the flat , bottom-dwelling platyctenids , the juveniles behave more like true larvae , as they live among the plankton and thus occupy a different ecological niche from their parents and attain the adult form by a more radical metamorphosis , after dropping to the sea-floor .	where do juvenile platyctenids live ?	as they live among the plankton and thus occupy a different ecological niche from their parents and attain the adult form by a more radical metamorphosis
in some groups , such as the flat , bottom-dwelling platyctenids , the juveniles behave more like true larvae , as they live among the plankton and thus occupy a different ecological niche from their parents and attain the adult form by a more radical metamorphosis , after dropping to the sea-floor .	when do juvenile develop into adults ?	as they live among the plankton and thus occupy a different ecological niche from their parents and attain the adult form by a more radical metamorphosis
in some groups , such as the flat , bottom-dwelling platyctenids , the juveniles behave more like true larvae , as they live among the plankton and thus occupy a different ecological niche from their parents and attain the adult form by a more radical metamorphosis , after dropping to the sea-floor .	juvenile platyctenids act like what ?	as they live among the plankton and thus occupy a different ecological niche from their parents and attain the adult form by a more radical metamorphosis
in the genus beroe the juveniles , like the adults , lack tentacles and tentacle sheaths .	which genus lack tentacles and sheaths ?	lack tentacles and tentacle sheaths
when some species , including bathyctena chuni , euplokamis stationis and eurhamphaea vexilligera , are disturbed , they produce secretions -lrb- ink -rrb- that luminesce at much the same wavelengths as their bodies .	what do bathyctena chuni , euplokamis stationis and eurhamphaea vexilligera have in common ?	they produce secretions -lrb- ink -rrb- that luminesce at much the same wavelengths as their bodies

when some species , including bathyctena chuni , euplokamis stationis and eurhamphaea vexilligera , are disturbed , they produce secretions -lrb- ink -rrb- that luminesce at much the same wavelengths as their bodies .	what are the secretions commonly called ?	they produce secretions -lrb- ink -rrb- that luminesce at much the same wavelengths as their bodies
juveniles will luminesce more brightly in relation to their body size than adults , whose luminescence is diffused over their bodies .	do adults or juveniles secretions luminesce brighter ?	juveniles will luminesce more brightly in relation to their body size than adults
almost all ctenophores are predators -- there are no vegetarians and only one genus that is partly parasitic .	are ctenophores predators , vegetarian or parasitic ?	almost all ctenophores are predators -- there are no vegetarians and only one genus that is partly parasitic
members of the genus haeckelia prey on jellyfish and incorporate their prey 's nematocysts -lrb- stinging cells -rrb- into their own tentacles instead of colloblasts .	haeckelia prey mostly on what animal ?	members of the genus haeckelia prey on jellyfish and incorporate their prey 's nematocysts -lrb- stinging cells -rrb- into their own tentacles instead of colloblasts
members of the genus haeckelia prey on jellyfish and incorporate their prey 's nematocysts -lrb- stinging cells -rrb- into their own tentacles instead of colloblasts .	what happens to the jellyfish nematocysts when they are eaten by the haeckelia ?	members of the genus haeckelia prey on jellyfish and incorporate their prey 's nematocysts -lrb- stinging cells -rrb- into their own tentacles instead of colloblasts
members of the cydippid genus pleurobrachia and the lobate bolinopsis often reach high population densities at the same place and time because they specialize in different types of prey : pleurobrachia 's long tentacles mainly capture relatively strong swimmers such as adult copepods , while bolinopsis generally feeds on smaller , weaker swimmers such as rotifers and mollusc and crustacean larvae .	what does the bolinopsis generally eat ?	members of the cydippid genus pleurobrachia and the lobate bolinopsis often reach high population densities at the same place and time because they specialize in different types of prey : pleurobrachia 's long tentacles mainly capture relatively strong swimmers such as adult copepods
the two-tentacled `` cydippid '' lampea feeds exclusively on salps , close relatives of sea-squirts that form large chain-like floating colonies , and juveniles of lampea attach themselves like parasites to salps that are too large for them to swallow .	what is the name of the two-tentacled cydippid that feedsentirely on salps called ?	and juveniles of lampea attach themselves like parasites to salps that are too large for them to swallow
ctenophores used to be regarded as `` dead ends '' in marine food chains because it was thought their low ratio of organic matter to salt and water made them a poor diet for other animals .	why was it thought that ctenophores were a poor diet for other animals ?	ctenophores used to be regarded as `` dead ends '' in marine food chains because it was thought their low ratio of organic matter to salt and water made them a poor diet for other animals
detailed investigation of chum salmon , oncorhynchus keta , showed that these fish digest ctenophores 20 times as fast as an equal weight of shrimps , and that ctenophores can provide a good diet if there are enough of them around .	what is the oncorhynchus also called ?	showed that these fish digest ctenophores 20 times as fast as an equal weight of shrimps
beroids prey mainly on other ctenophores .	what do beroids typically eat ?	beroids prey mainly on other ctenophores
this is underlined by an observation of herbivorous fishes deliberately feeding on gelatinous zooplankton during blooms in the red sea .	where have herbivorous fishes been seen feeding on gelatinous zooplankton ?	this is underlined by an observation of herbivorous fishes deliberately feeding on gelatinous zooplankton during blooms in the red sea
some jellyfish and turtles eat large quantities of ctenophores , and jellyfish may temporarily wipe out ctenophore populations .	turtles and jellyfish can eat large quantities of what ?	some jellyfish and turtles eat large quantities of ctenophores
on the other hand , in the late 1980s the western atlantic ctenophore mnemiopsis leidyi was accidentally introduced into the black sea and sea of azov via the ballast tanks of ships , and has been blamed for causing sharp drops in fish catches by eating both fish larvae and small crustaceans that would otherwise feed the adult fish .	what is blamed for causing the sharp drop in fish catches in the black sea and the sea of azov ?	in the late 1980s the western atlantic ctenophore mnemiopsis leidyi was accidentally introduced into the black sea and sea of azov via the ballast tanks of ships
on the other hand , in the late 1980s the western atlantic ctenophore mnemiopsis leidyi was accidentally introduced into the black sea and sea of azov via the ballast tanks of ships , and has been blamed for causing sharp drops in fish catches by eating both fish larvae and small crustaceans that would otherwise feed the adult fish .	how was the ctenophore mnemiopsis leidyi introduced into the black sea and the sea of azov ?	in the late 1980s the western atlantic ctenophore mnemiopsis leidyi was accidentally introduced into the black sea and sea of azov via the ballast tanks of ships
mnemiopsis populations in those areas were eventually brought under control by the accidental introduction of the mnemiopsis-eating north american ctenophore beroe ovata , and by a cooling of the local climate from 1991 to 1993 , which significantly slowed the animal 's metabolism .	how was the population of mnemiopsis in the black sea and the sea of azov brought under control ?	mnemiopsis populations in those areas were eventually brought under control by the accidental introduction of the mnemiopsis-eating north american ctenophore beroe ovata
on the other hand , in the late 1980s the western atlantic ctenophore mnemiopsis leidyi was accidentally introduced into the black sea and sea of azov via the ballast tanks of ships , and has been blamed for causing sharp drops in fish catches by eating both fish larvae and small crustaceans that would otherwise feed the adult fish .	when was ctenophore mnemiopsis leidyi introduced into the black sea and the sea of azov ?	in the late 1980s the western atlantic ctenophore mnemiopsis leidyi was accidentally introduced into the black sea and sea of azov via the ballast tanks of ships
mnemiopsis populations in those areas were eventually brought under control by the accidental introduction of the mnemiopsis-eating north american ctenophore beroe ovata , and by a cooling of the local climate from 1991 to 1993 , which significantly slowed the animal 's metabolism .	how does cooling of the local environment affect the mnemiopsis ?	mnemiopsis populations in those areas were eventually brought under control by the accidental introduction of the mnemiopsis-eating north american ctenophore beroe ovata
because of their soft , gelatinous bodies , ctenophores are extremely rare as fossils , and fossils that have been interpreted as ctenophores have been found only in lagerstätten , places where the environment was exceptionally suited to preservation of soft tissue .	why are ctenophores extremely rare as fossils ?	and fossils that have been interpreted as ctenophores have been found only in lagerstätten
the ediacaran eoandromeda could putatively represent a comb jelly .	ediacaran eoandromeda can be regarded to represent what ?	the ediacaran eoandromeda could putatively represent a comb jelly
three additional putative species were then found in the burgess shale and other canadian rocks of similar age , about 505 million years ago in the mid-cambrian period .	what was the period called that was 505 million years ago ?	three additional putative species were then found in the burgess shale and other canadian rocks of similar age
three additional putative species were then found in the burgess shale and other canadian rocks of similar age , about 505 million years ago in the mid-cambrian period .	how many species were found in the burgess shale ?	three additional putative species were then found in the burgess shale and other canadian rocks of similar age
all three apparently lacked tentacles but had between 24 and 80 comb rows , far more than the 8 typical of living species .	what did the fossils found in the burgess shale lack ?	all three apparently lacked tentacles but had between 24 and 80 comb rows
the early cambrian sessile frond-like fossil stromatoveris , from china 's chengjiang lagerstätte and dated to about 515 million years ago , is very similar to vendobionta of the preceding ediacaran period .	how old were the fossils found in china ?	from china 's chengjiang lagerstätte and dated to about 515 million years ago
the early cambrian sessile frond-like fossil stromatoveris , from china 's chengjiang lagerstätte and dated to about 515 million years ago , is very similar to vendobionta of the preceding ediacaran period .	what type of fossils were found in china ?	from china 's chengjiang lagerstätte and dated to about 515 million years ago
they suggested that stromatoveris was an evolutionary `` aunt '' of ctenophores , and that ctenophores originated from sessile animals whose descendants became swimmers and changed the cilia from a feeding mechanism to a propulsion system .	which genus is considered the `` aunt '' of ctenophores ?	and that ctenophores originated from sessile animals whose descendants became swimmers and changed the cilia from a feeding mechanism to a propulsion system
the early cambrian sessile frond-like fossil stromatoveris , from china 's chengjiang lagerstätte and dated to about 515 million years ago , is very similar to vendobionta of the preceding ediacaran period .	stromatoveris is similair to which genus ?	from china 's chengjiang lagerstätte and dated to about 515 million years ago
the early cambrian sessile frond-like fossil stromatoveris , from china 's chengjiang lagerstätte and dated to about 515 million years ago , is very similar to vendobionta of the preceding ediacaran period .	vendobionta lived during which period ?	from china 's chengjiang lagerstätte and dated to about 515 million years ago
several more recent studies comparing complete sequenced genomes of ctenophores with other sequenced animal genomes have also supported ctenophores as the sister lineage to all other animals .	recent studies believe that ctenophores are the sister lineage to what ?	several more recent studies comparing complete sequenced genomes of ctenophores with other sequenced animal genomes have also supported ctenophores as the sister lineage to all other animals
however , other researchers have argued that the placement of ctenophora as sister to all other animals is a statistical anomaly caused by the high rate of evolution in ctenophore genomes , and that porifera -lrb- sponges -rrb- is the earliest-diverging animal phylum instead .	what do some researchers believe is the earliest-diverging animal phylum is ?	other researchers have argued that the placement of ctenophora as sister to all other animals is a statistical anomaly caused by the high rate of evolution in ctenophore genomes
since all modern ctenophores except the beroids have cydippid-like larvae , it has widely been assumed that their last common ancestor also resembled cydippids , having an egg-shaped body and a pair of retractable tentacles .	which genus of ctenophores does not have cydipped-like larvae ?	it has widely been assumed that their last common ancestor also resembled cydippids
a molecular phylogeny analysis in 2001 , using 26 species , including 4 recently discovered ones , confirmed that the cydippids are not monophyletic and concluded that the last common ancestor of modern ctenophores was cydippid-like .	a molecular phylogeny analysis confirmed that cydippid are not what ?	confirmed that the cydippids are not monophyletic and concluded that the last common ancestor of modern ctenophores was cydippid-like
this suggests that the last common ancestor of modern ctenophores was relatively recent , and perhaps was lucky enough to survive the cretaceous -- paleogene extinction event 65.5 million years ago while other lineages perished .	when was the cretaceous-paleogen extinction occur ?	and perhaps was lucky enough to survive the cretaceous -- paleogene extinction event 65
richard harbison 's purely morphological analysis in 1985 concluded that the cydippids are not monophyletic , in other words do not contain all and only the descendants of a single common ancestor that was itself a cydippid .	who did a morphologically analysis in 1985 that concluded cydippids are not monophyletic ?	in other words do not contain all and only the descendants of a single common ancestor that was itself a cydippid
fresno -lrb- / ˈfrɛznoʊ / frez-noh -rrb- , the county seat of fresno county , is a city in the u.s. state of california .	which city is the fifth-largest city in california ?	fresno -lrb- / ˈfrɛznoʊ / frez-noh -rrb-
it is approximately 220 miles -lrb- 350 km -rrb- northwest of los angeles , 170 miles -lrb- 270 km -rrb- south of the state capital , sacramento , or 185 miles -lrb- 300 km -rrb- south of san francisco .	how far is fresno from los angeles ?	it is approximately 220 miles -lrb- 350 km -rrb- northwest of los angeles
the name fresno means `` ash tree '' in spanish , and an ash leaf is featured on the city 's flag .	what does the name fresno mean in spanish ?	and an ash leaf is featured on the city 's flag

fresno -lrb- / ˈfrɛznoʊ / frez-noh -rrb- , the county seat of fresno county , is a city in the u.s. state of california .	how do you pronounce fresno ?	fresno -lrb- / ˈfrɛznoʊ / frez-noh -rrb-
in 1872 , the central pacific railroad established a station near easterby 's -- by now a hugely productive wheat farm -- for its new southern pacific line .	the central pacific railroad established a station for its new line in what year ?	the central pacific railroad established a station near easterby 's -- by now a hugely productive wheat farm -- for its new southern pacific line
many millerton residents , drawn by the convenience of the railroad and worried about flooding , moved to the new community .	what were the reasons why residents moved to the town of fresno station ?	drawn by the convenience of the railroad and worried about flooding
fresno became an incorporated city in 1885 .	in what year did fresno become an incorporated city ?	fresno became an incorporated city in 1885
by 1931 the fresno traction company operated 47 streetcars over 49 miles of track .	how many streetcars did the fresno traction company operate in 1931 ?	by 1931 the fresno traction company operated 47 streetcars over 49 miles of track
soon there was a store around the station and the store grew the town of fresno station , later called fresno .	what entity sparked the growth of fresno station ?	soon there was a store around the station and the store grew the town of fresno station

during 1942 , pinedale , in what is now north fresno , was the site of the pinedale assembly center , an interim facility for the relocation of fresno area japanese americans to internment camps .	in 1942 , what was north fresno previously called ?	an interim facility for the relocation of fresno area japanese americans to internment camps

in september 1958 , bank of america launched a new product called bankamericard in fresno .	what new product did bank of america introduce in 1958 ?	bank of america launched a new product called bankamericard in fresno
in september 1958 , bank of america launched a new product called bankamericard in fresno .	what was the name of the first successful credit card ?	bank of america launched a new product called bankamericard in fresno
after a troubled gestation during which its creator resigned , bankamericard went on to become the first successful credit card ; that is , a financial instrument that was usable across a large number of merchants and also allowed cardholders to revolve a balance -lrb- earlier financial products could do one or the other but not both -rrb- .	what did the bankamericard allow customers do to that they could n't do with previous financial instruments ?	a financial instrument that was usable across a large number of merchants and also allowed cardholders to revolve a balance -lrb- earlier financial products could do one or the other but not both -rrb-
in 1976 , bankamericard was renamed and spun off into a separate company known today as visa inc. .	in what year did bankamericard change its name ?	bankamericard was renamed and spun off into a separate company known today as visa inc
in 1976 , bankamericard was renamed and spun off into a separate company known today as visa inc. .	what present-day company did bankamericard turn into ?	bankamericard was renamed and spun off into a separate company known today as visa inc

''	written by hall of fame guitarist bill aken and recorded by bob gallion of the world-famous `` wwva jamboree '' radio and television show in wheeling

fresno has three large public parks , two in the city limits and one in county land to the southwest .	how many large public parks does fresno have ?	two in the city limits and one in county land to the southwest

kearney park is the largest of the fresno region 's park system and is home to historic kearney mansion and plays host to the annual civil war revisited , the largest reenactment of the civil war in the west coast of the u.s.	which park is home to the kearney mansion ?	kearney park is the largest of the fresno region 's park system and is home to historic kearney mansion and plays host to the annual civil war revisited

between the 1880s and world war ii , downtown fresno flourished , filled with electric street cars , and contained some of the san joaquin valley 's most beautiful architectural buildings .	during what period did downtown fresno thrive ?	and contained some of the san joaquin valley 's most beautiful architectural buildings
among them , the original fresno county courthouse -lrb- demolished -rrb- , the fresno carnegie public library -lrb- demolished -rrb- , the fresno water tower , the bank of italy building , the pacific southwest building , the san joaquin light & power building -lrb- currently known as the grand 1401 -rrb- , and the hughes hotel -lrb- burned down -rrb- , to name a few .	what were two of fresno 's most beautiful architectural buildings that are now demolished ?	the san joaquin light & power building -lrb- currently known as the grand 1401 -rrb-

fulton street in downtown fresno was fresno 's main financial and commercial district before being converted into one of the nation 's first pedestrian malls in 1964 .	in what year did fresno get its first pedestrian mall ?	fulton street in downtown fresno was fresno 's main financial and commercial district before being converted into one of the nation 's first pedestrian malls in 1964
renamed the fulton mall , the area contains the densest collection of historic buildings in fresno .	what was the pedestrian mall renamed ?	the area contains the densest collection of historic buildings in fresno
while the fulton mall corridor has suffered a sharp decline from its heyday , the mall includes some of the finest public art pieces in the country , including the only pierre-auguste renoir piece in the world that one can walk up to and touch .	which artist has a piece of his artwork located at the fulton mall ?	including the only pierre-auguste renoir piece in the world that one can walk up to and touch

the popular neighborhood known as the tower district is centered around the historic tower theatre , which is included on the national list of historic places .	the tower district is centered around which historic theatre ?	the popular neighborhood known as the tower district is centered around the historic tower theatre
the theater was built in 1939 and is at olive and wishon avenues in the heart of the tower district .	when was the tower theatre built ?	the theater was built in 1939 and is at olive and wishon avenues in the heart of the tower district
-lrb- the name of the theater refers to a well-known landmark water tower , which is actually in another nearby area -rrb- .	from what landmark within fresno does the tower theatre get its name ?	-lrb- the name of the theater refers to a well-known landmark water tower

the alta vista tract , as the land would become known , was mapped by william stranahan for the pacific improvement corporation , and was officially platted in 1911 .	who mapped the alta vista tract ?	was mapped by william stranahan for the pacific improvement corporation
in 1914 developers billings & meyering acquired the tract , completed street development , provided the last of the necessary municipal improvements including water service , and began marketing the property with fervor .	in what year did developers billings & meyering acquire the alta vista tract ?	provided the last of the necessary municipal improvements including water service
a mere half decade later the tract had 267 homes .	how many homes did the alta vista tract have five years after billings & meyering acquired it ?	a mere half decade later the tract had 267 homes
this rapid development was no doubt hastened by the fresno traction company right-of-way along huntington boulevard , which provided streetcar connections between downtown and the county hospital .	which company provided streetcar connections between downtown and the hospital ?	this rapid development was no doubt hastened by the fresno traction company right-of-way along huntington boulevard
the `` west side '' of fresno , also often called `` southwest fresno '' , is one of the oldest neighborhoods in the city .	what is another name for the west side of fresno ?	is one of the oldest neighborhoods in the city
the neighborhood lies southwest of the 99 freeway -lrb- which divides it from downtown fresno -rrb- , west of the 41 freeway and south of nielsen ave -lrb- or the newly constructed 180 freeway -rrb- , and extends to the city limits to the west and south .	in which direction does the west side of fresno neighborhood lie to the 99 freeway ?	the neighborhood lies southwest of the 99 freeway -lrb- which divides it from downtown fresno -rrb-
the neighborhood is traditionally considered to be the center of fresno 's african-american community .	the west side of fresno is the center of which ethnic community ?	the neighborhood is traditionally considered to be the center of fresno 's african-american community

the neighborhood includes kearney boulevard , named after early 20th century entrepreneur and millionaire m. theo kearney , which extends from fresno street in southwest fresno about 20 mi -lrb- 32 km -rrb- west to kerman , california .	who is kearney boulevard named after ?	which extends from fresno street in southwest fresno about 20 mi -lrb- 32 km -rrb- west to kerman
a small , two-lane rural road for most of its length , kearney boulevard is lined with tall palm trees .	what kinds of trees is kearney boulevard lined with ?	kearney boulevard is lined with tall palm trees
the roughly half-mile stretch of kearney boulevard between fresno street and thorne ave was at one time the preferred neighborhood for fresno 's elite african-american families .	between which two streets along kearney boulevard were wealthy african-americans at one time residing ?	the roughly half-mile stretch of kearney boulevard between fresno street and thorne ave was at one time the preferred neighborhood for fresno 's elite african-american families

the isolated subdivision was for years known as the `` dogg pound '' in reference to a local gang , and as of late 2008 was still known for high levels of violent crime .	what area of brookhaven is still known for its high levels of crime ?	the isolated subdivision was for years known as the `` dogg pound '' in reference to a local gang
while many homes in the neighborhood date back to the 1930s or before , the neighborhood is also home to several public housing developments built between the 1960s and 1990s by the fresno housing authority .	when were the public housing developments built in the neighborhood ?	the neighborhood is also home to several public housing developments built between the 1960s and 1990s by the fresno housing authority
there have been numerous attempts to revitalize the neighborhood , including the construction of a modern shopping center on the corner of fresno and b streets , an aborted attempt to build luxury homes and a golf course on the western edge of the neighborhood , and some new section 8 apartments have been built along church ave west of elm st. cargill meat solutions and foster farms both have large processing facilities in the neighborhood , and the stench from these -lrb- and other small industrial facilities -rrb- has long plagued area residents .	on which corner is the shopping center located ?	and the stench from these -lrb- and other small industrial facilities -rrb- has long plagued area residents

in the north eastern part of fresno , woodward park was founded by the late ralph woodward , a long-time fresno resident .	who founded woodward park ?	woodward park was founded by the late ralph woodward
the initial 235 acres -lrb- 0.95 km2 -rrb- , combined with additional acres acquired later by the city , brings the park to a sizable 300 acres -lrb- 1.2 km2 -rrb- .	how many total acres is woodward park ?	combined with additional acres acquired later by the city
the park has a multi-use amphitheatre that seats up to 2,500 people , authentic japanese garden , fenced dog park , two-mile -lrb- 3 km -rrb- equestrian trail , exercise par course , three children 's playgrounds , a lake , 3 small ponds , 7 picnic areas and five miles -lrb- 8 km -rrb- of multipurpose trails that are part of the san joaquin river parkway 's lewis s. eaton trail .	how many seats does the amphitheatre at woodward park have ?	7 picnic areas and five miles -lrb- 8 km -rrb- of multipurpose trails that are part of the san joaquin river parkway 's lewis s

fresno is marked by a semi-arid climate -lrb- köppen bsh -rrb- , with mild , moist winters and hot and dry summers , thus displaying mediterranean characteristics .	how would one describe the summers in fresno ?	fresno is marked by a semi-arid climate -lrb- köppen bsh -rrb-
july is the warmest month , averaging 83.0 °f -lrb- 28.3 °c -rrb- ; normally , there are 32 days of 100 °f -lrb- 37.8 °c -rrb- + highs and 106 days of 90 °f -lrb- 32.2 °c -rrb- + highs , and in july and august , there are only three or four days where the high does not reach 90 °f -lrb- 32.2 °c -rrb- .	what month is the warmest in fresno ?	there are only three or four days where the high does not reach 90 °f -lrb- 32

starting in the late 1950s , american computer scientist paul baran developed the concept distributed adaptive message block switching with the goal to provide a fault-tolerant , efficient routing method for telecommunication messages as part of a research program at the rand corporation , funded by the us department of defense .	what did paul baran develop	american computer scientist paul baran developed the concept distributed adaptive message block switching with the goal to provide a fault-tolerant
starting in the late 1950s , american computer scientist paul baran developed the concept distributed adaptive message block switching with the goal to provide a fault-tolerant , efficient routing method for telecommunication messages as part of a research program at the rand corporation , funded by the us department of defense .	what did distributed adaptive message block switching do	american computer scientist paul baran developed the concept distributed adaptive message block switching with the goal to provide a fault-tolerant
this concept contrasted and contradicted the theretofore established principles of pre-allocation of network bandwidth , largely fortified by the development of telecommunications in the bell system .	what did this concept contradict	this concept contrasted and contradicted the theretofore established principles of pre-allocation of network bandwidth
davies is credited with coining the modern name packet switching and inspiring numerous packet switching networks in europe in the decade following , including the incorporation of the concept in the early arpanet in the united states .	what is donald davies credited with	davies is credited with coining the modern name packet switching and inspiring numerous packet switching networks in europe in the decade following

packet switching contrasts with another principal networking paradigm , circuit switching , a method which pre-allocates dedicated network bandwidth specifically for each communication session , each having a constant bit rate and latency between nodes .	packet switching contrast with what other principal	a method which pre-allocates dedicated network bandwidth specifically for each communication session
in cases of billable services , such as cellular communication services , circuit switching is characterized by a fee per unit of connection time , even when no data is transferred , while packet switching may be characterized by a fee per unit of information transmitted , such as characters , packets , or messages .	what is circuit switching characterized by	while packet switching may be characterized by a fee per unit of information transmitted

packet mode communication may be implemented with or without intermediate forwarding nodes -lrb- packet switches or routers -rrb- .	how is packet mode communication implemented	packet mode communication may be implemented with or without intermediate forwarding nodes -lrb- packet switches or routers -rrb-
packets are normally forwarded by intermediate network nodes asynchronously using first-in , first-out buffering , but may be forwarded according to some scheduling discipline for fair queuing , traffic shaping , or for differentiated or guaranteed quality of service , such as weighted fair queuing or leaky bucket .	how are packets normally forwarded	packets are normally forwarded by intermediate network nodes asynchronously using first-in
in case of a shared physical medium -lrb- such as radio or 10base5 -rrb- , the packets may be delivered according to a multiple access scheme .	in cases of shared physical medium how are they delivered	in case of a shared physical medium -lrb- such as radio or 10base5 -rrb-

baran developed the concept of distributed adaptive message block switching during his research at the rand corporation for the us air force into survivable communications networks , first presented to the air force in the summer of 1961 as briefing b-265 , later published as rand report p-2626 in 1962 , and finally in report rm 3420 in 1964 .	what did baran develop during research at rand	baran developed the concept of distributed adaptive message block switching during his research at the rand corporation for the us air force into survivable communications networks
baran developed the concept of distributed adaptive message block switching during his research at the rand corporation for the us air force into survivable communications networks , first presented to the air force in the summer of 1961 as briefing b-265 , later published as rand report p-2626 in 1962 , and finally in report rm 3420 in 1964 .	what was developed for the air force	baran developed the concept of distributed adaptive message block switching during his research at the rand corporation for the us air force into survivable communications networks
the work focuses on three key ideas : use of a decentralized network with multiple paths between any two points , dividing user messages into message blocks , later called packets , and delivery of these messages by store and forward switching .	what 3 things does the air force work key on	the work focuses on three key ideas : use of a decentralized network with multiple paths between any two points

in connectionless mode each packet includes complete addressing information .	what does each packet includ in connectionless mode	in connectionless mode each packet includes complete addressing information
the packets are routed individually , sometimes resulting in different paths and out-of-order delivery .	how are the packets routed	sometimes resulting in different paths and out-of-order delivery
each packet is labeled with a destination address , source address , and port numbers .	what is included with each packet label	each packet is labeled with a destination address
at the destination , the original message/data is reassembled in the correct order , based on the packet sequence number .	what happens to the packet at the destination	the original message/data is reassembled in the correct order
the packet header can be small , as it only needs to contain this code and any information , such as length , timestamp , or sequence number , which is different for different packets .	is the packet header long	as it only needs to contain this code and any information
routing a packet requires the node to look up the connection id in a table .	why is the node requiered to look up	routing a packet requires the node to look up the connection id in a table
the packets include a connection identifier rather than address information and are negotiated between endpoints so that they are delivered in order and with error checking .	what is a connection identifier	the packets include a connection identifier rather than address information and are negotiated between endpoints so that they are delivered in order and with error checking
connection-oriented transmission requires a setup phase in each involved node before any packet is transferred to establish the parameters of communication .	what does connection orientation require	connection-oriented transmission requires a setup phase in each involved node before any packet is transferred to establish the parameters of communication
both x. 25 and frame relay provide connection-oriented operations .	what do x. 25 and frame relay both require	25 and frame relay provide connection-oriented operations
however , x. 25 and well as frame relay have been supplanted by the internet protocol -lrb- ip -rrb- at the network layer , and the asynchronous transfer mode -lrb- atm -rrb- and or versions of multi-protocol label switching -lrb- mpls -rrb- at layer two .	what supplanted frame relay and x. 25	and the asynchronous transfer mode -lrb- atm -rrb- and or versions of multi-protocol label switching -lrb- mpls -rrb- at layer two
for a while , frame relay was used to interconnect lans across wide area networks .	what were x. 25 and frame relay used for	frame relay was used to interconnect lans across wide area networks
a typical configuration is to run ip over atm or a version of mpls .	what is a typical configuration	a typical configuration is to run ip over atm or a version of mpls

two fundamental differences involved the division of functions and tasks between the hosts at the edge of the network and the network core .	2 differences betwen x. 25 and arpnet cita technologies	two fundamental differences involved the division of functions and tasks between the hosts at the edge of the network and the network core
in the virtual call system , the network guarantees sequenced delivery of data to the host .	what does userdatagram protocol gaurentee	the network guarantees sequenced delivery of data to the host
the user datagram protocol -lrb- udp -rrb- is an example of a datagram protocol .	x. 25 uses what type network type	the user datagram protocol -lrb- udp -rrb- is an example of a datagram protocol
appletalk was a proprietary suite of networking protocols developed by apple inc. in 1985 for apple macintosh computers .	what was apple talk	appletalk was a proprietary suite of networking protocols developed by apple inc
appletalk included features that allowed local area networks to be established ad hoc without the requirement for a centralized router or server .	what were features of apple talk	appletalk included features that allowed local area networks to be established ad hoc without the requirement for a centralized router or server
the appletalk system automatically assigned addresses , updated the distributed namespace , and configured any required inter-network routing .	what did the apple system assign automatically	the appletalk system automatically assigned addresses
it was a plug-n-play system .	this type of system is known as	it was a plug-n-play system
the cyclades packet switching network was a french research network designed and directed by louis pouzin .	what network was designed by the french	the cyclades packet switching network was a french research network designed and directed by louis pouzin
it was the first network to make the hosts responsible for reliable delivery of data , rather than the network itself , using unreliable datagrams and associated end-to-end protocol mechanisms .	what was a first for this network	it was the first network to make the hosts responsible for reliable delivery of data
it was the first network to make the hosts responsible for reliable delivery of data , rather than the network itself , using unreliable datagrams and associated end-to-end protocol mechanisms .	how was this possible	it was the first network to make the hosts responsible for reliable delivery of data

merit network , inc. , an independent non-profit 501 -lrb- c -rrb- -lrb- 3 -rrb- corporation governed by michigan 's public universities , was formed in 1966 as the michigan educational research information triad to explore computer networking between three of michigan 's public universities as a means to help the state 's educational and economic development .	why was the merit network formed in michigan	was formed in 1966 as the michigan educational research information triad to explore computer networking between three of michigan 's public universities as a means to help the state 's educational and economic development
with initial support from the state of michigan and the national science foundation -lrb- nsf -rrb- , the packet-switched network was first demonstrated in december 1971 when an interactive host to host connection was made between the ibm mainframe computer systems at the university of michigan in ann arbor and wayne state university in detroit .	what completed the triad	the packet-switched network was first demonstrated in december 1971 when an interactive host to host connection was made between the ibm mainframe computer systems at the university of michigan in ann arbor and wayne state university in detroit
over the next several years in addition to host to host interactive connections the network was enhanced to support terminal to host connections , host to host batch connections -lrb- remote job submission , remote printing , batch file transfer -rrb- , interactive file transfer , gateways to the tymnet and telenet public data networks , x. 25 host attachments , gateways to x. 25 data networks , ethernet attached hosts , and eventually tcp/ip and additional public universities in michigan join the network .	what set the stage for merits role in nsfnet	over the next several years in addition to host to host interactive connections the network was enhanced to support terminal to host connections

tymnet was an international data communications network headquartered in san jose , ca that utilized virtual call packet switched technology and used x. 25 , sna/sdlc , bsc and ascii interfaces to connect host computers -lrb- servers -rrb- at thousands of large companies , educational institutions , and government agencies .	what was tymnet	bsc and ascii interfaces to connect host computers -lrb- servers -rrb- at thousands of large companies
tymnet was an international data communications network headquartered in san jose , ca that utilized virtual call packet switched technology and used x. 25 , sna/sdlc , bsc and ascii interfaces to connect host computers -lrb- servers -rrb- at thousands of large companies , educational institutions , and government agencies .	what did tymnet connect	bsc and ascii interfaces to connect host computers -lrb- servers -rrb- at thousands of large companies
users typically connected via dial-up connections or dedicated async connections .	how did user of tymnet connect	users typically connected via dial-up connections or dedicated async connections
the business consisted of a large public network that supported dial-up users and a private network business that allowed government agencies and large companies -lrb- mostly banks and airlines -rrb- to build their own dedicated networks .	the business allowed for private companies to do what	the business consisted of a large public network that supported dial-up users and a private network business that allowed government agencies and large companies -lrb- mostly banks and airlines -rrb- to build their own dedicated networks
the private networks were often connected via gateways to the public network to reach locations not on the private network .	gateways allowed private companies to do what	the private networks were often connected via gateways to the public network to reach locations not on the private network

austpac was an australian public x. 25 network operated by telstra .	what was austpac	austpac was an australian public x
started by telecom australia in the early 1980s , austpac was australia 's first public packet-switched data network , supporting applications such as on-line betting , financial applications -- the australian tax office made use of austpac -- and remote terminal access to academic institutions , who maintained their connections to austpac up until the mid-late 1990s in some cases .	what did austpac support	financial applications -- the australian tax office made use of austpac -- and remote terminal access to academic institutions

it played a significant role in spreading awareness of , and access to , national networking and was a major milestone on the path to development of the global internet .	funding limitations allowed csnet to be what	national networking and was a major milestone on the path to development of the global internet

the national science foundation network -lrb- nsfnet -rrb- was a program of coordinated , evolving projects sponsored by the national science foundation -lrb- nsf -rrb- beginning in 1985 to promote advanced research and education networking in the united states .	what did nsfnet promote	evolving projects sponsored by the national science foundation -lrb- nsf -rrb- beginning in 1985 to promote advanced research and education networking in the united states
initially created to link researchers to the nation 's nsf-funded supercomputing centers , through further public funding and private industry partnerships it developed into a major part of the internet backbone .	what did nsfnet eventually provide	through further public funding and private industry partnerships it developed into a major part of the internet backbone
the very high-speed backbone network service -lrb- vbns -rrb- came on line in april 1995 as part of a national science foundation -lrb- nsf -rrb- sponsored project to provide high-speed interconnection between nsf-sponsored supercomputing centers and select access points in the united states .	what does vbns stand for	the very high-speed backbone network service -lrb- vbns -rrb- came on line in april 1995 as part of a national science foundation -lrb- nsf -rrb- sponsored project to provide high-speed interconnection between nsf-sponsored supercomputing centers and select access points in the united states

by 1998 , the vbns had grown to connect more than 100 universities and research and engineering institutions via 12 national points of presence with ds-3 -lrb- 45 mbit/s -rrb- , oc-3c -lrb- 155 mbit/s -rrb- , and oc-12c -lrb- 622 mbit/s -rrb- links on an all oc-12c backbone , a substantial engineering feat for that time .	by 199 how many universities were connected	the vbns had grown to connect more than 100 universities and research and engineering institutions via 12 national points of presence with ds-3 -lrb- 45 mbit/s -rrb-

the black death is thought to have originated in the arid plains of central asia , where it then travelled along the silk road , reaching crimea by 1343 .	where did the black death originate ?	the black death is thought to have originated in the arid plains of central asia
from there , it was most likely carried by oriental rat fleas living on the black rats that were regular passengers on merchant ships .	how did the black death make it to the mediterranean and europe ?	it was most likely carried by oriental rat fleas living on the black rats that were regular passengers on merchant ships
spreading throughout the mediterranean and europe , the black death is estimated to have killed 30 -- 60 % of europe 's total population .	how much of the european population did the black death kill ?	the black death is estimated to have killed 30 -- 60 % of europe 's total population
the world population as a whole did not recover to pre-plague levels until the 17th century .	when did the world 's population finally recover from the black death ?	the world population as a whole did not recover to pre-plague levels until the 17th century
the plague recurred occasionally in europe until the 19th century .	for how long did the plague stick around ?	the plague recurred occasionally in europe until the 19th century
the plague disease , caused by yersinia pestis , is enzootic -lrb- commonly present -rrb- in populations of fleas carried by ground rodents , including marmots , in various areas including central asia , kurdistan , western asia , northern india and uganda .	what does it mean for a disease to be enzootic ?	is enzootic -lrb- commonly present -rrb- in populations of fleas carried by ground rodents
nestorian graves dating to 1338 -- 39 near lake issyk kul in kyrgyzstan have inscriptions referring to plague and are thought by many epidemiologists to mark the outbreak of the epidemic , from which it could easily have spread to china and india .	how old are the gravestones that reference the plague ?	nestorian graves dating to 1338 -- 39 near lake issyk kul in kyrgyzstan have inscriptions referring to plague and are thought by many epidemiologists to mark the outbreak of the epidemic

the mechanism by which y. pestis was usually transmitted was established in 1898 by paul-louis simond and was found to involve the bites of fleas whose midguts had become obstructed by replicating y. pestis several days after feeding on an infected host .	what did paul-louis simond establish in 1898 ?	pestis was usually transmitted was established in 1898 by paul-louis simond and was found to involve the bites of fleas whose midguts had become obstructed by replicating y

the modern bubonic plague has a mortality rate of 30 -- 75 % and symptoms including fever of 38 -- 41 °c -lrb- 100 -- 106 °f -rrb- , headaches , painful aching joints , nausea and vomiting , and a general feeling of malaise .	what is the mortality rate of the modern bubonic plague ?	the modern bubonic plague has a mortality rate of 30 -- 75 % and symptoms including fever of 38 -- 41 °c -lrb- 100 -- 106 °f -rrb-

the authors concluded that this new research , together with prior analyses from the south of france and germany , '' ... ends the debate about the etiology of the black death , and unambiguously demonstrates that y. pestis was the causative agent of the epidemic plague that devastated europe during the middle ages '' .	what does the plos pathogen paper claim ?	pestis was the causative agent of the epidemic plague that devastated europe during the middle ages ''
