the university was a founding member of the big ten conference and participated in the ncaa division i men 's basketball and football and was a regular participant in the men 's basketball tournament .	the university was a founding force behind what conference ?	the university was a founding member of the big ten conference and participated in the ncaa division i men 's basketball and football and was a regular participant in the men 's basketball tournament
in 1935 , chicago maroons football player jay berwanger became the first winner of the heisman trophy .	what player first won the heisman trophy for the university ?	chicago maroons football player jay berwanger became the first winner of the heisman trophy
however , the university chose to withdraw from the conference in 1946 after university president robert maynard hutchins de-emphasized varsity athletics in 1939 and dropped football .	why did the university eventually leave the conference ?	the university chose to withdraw from the conference in 1946 after university president robert maynard hutchins de-emphasized varsity athletics in 1939 and dropped football
students at the university of chicago run over 400 clubs and organizations known as recognized student organizations -lrb- rsos -rrb- .	roughly how many clubs are ran at the university ?	students at the university of chicago run over 400 clubs and organizations known as recognized student organizations -lrb- rsos -rrb-
students at the university of chicago run over 400 clubs and organizations known as recognized student organizations -lrb- rsos -rrb- .	what is the name of the organization in charge of running the clubs at the university ?	students at the university of chicago run over 400 clubs and organizations known as recognized student organizations -lrb- rsos -rrb-
notable extracurricular groups include the university of chicago college bowl team , which has won 118 tournaments and 15 national championships , leading both categories internationally .	what club won 118 tournaments and 15 national championships ?	notable extracurricular groups include the university of chicago college bowl team
among notable rsos are the nation 's longest continuously running student film society doc films , organizing committee for the university of chicago scavenger hunt , the twice-weekly student newspaper the chicago maroon , the alternative weekly student newspaper south side weekly , the nation 's second oldest continuously running student improvisational theater troupe off-off campus , and the university-owned radio station whpk .	what is the name of the country 's longest continuously running student film society ?	the nation 's second oldest continuously running student improvisational theater troupe off-off campus
among notable rsos are the nation 's longest continuously running student film society doc films , organizing committee for the university of chicago scavenger hunt , the twice-weekly student newspaper the chicago maroon , the alternative weekly student newspaper south side weekly , the nation 's second oldest continuously running student improvisational theater troupe off-off campus , and the university-owned radio station whpk .	what is the name of the student improvisational theater troupe ?	the nation 's second oldest continuously running student improvisational theater troupe off-off campus
student government is made up of graduate and undergraduate students elected to represent members from their respective academic unit .	who makes up the student government ?	student government is made up of graduate and undergraduate students elected to represent members from their respective academic unit
it is led by an executive committee , chaired by a president with the assistance of two vice presidents , one for administration and the other for student life , elected together as a slate by the student body each spring .	who leads the student government ?	chaired by a president with the assistance of two vice presidents
it is led by an executive committee , chaired by a president with the assistance of two vice presidents , one for administration and the other for student life , elected together as a slate by the student body each spring .	how many vice presidents are on the student board ?	chaired by a president with the assistance of two vice presidents
its annual budget is greater than $ 2 million .	roughly how much is the student government 's budget ?	its annual budget is greater than $ 2 million
there are fifteen fraternities and seven sororities at the university of chicago , as well as one co-ed community service fraternity , alpha phi omega .	how many fraternities are apart of the university ?	there are fifteen fraternities and seven sororities at the university of chicago
there are fifteen fraternities and seven sororities at the university of chicago , as well as one co-ed community service fraternity , alpha phi omega .	how many sororities are apart of the university ?	there are fifteen fraternities and seven sororities at the university of chicago
there are fifteen fraternities and seven sororities at the university of chicago , as well as one co-ed community service fraternity , alpha phi omega .	what is the name of the co-ed community service fraternity ?	there are fifteen fraternities and seven sororities at the university of chicago
there are fifteen fraternities and seven sororities at the university of chicago , as well as one co-ed community service fraternity , alpha phi omega .	how many sororities belong to the national panhellenic conference ?	there are fifteen fraternities and seven sororities at the university of chicago
four of the sororities are members of the national panhellenic conference , and ten of the fraternities form the university of chicago interfraternity council .	how many fraternities form the university of chicago interfraternity council ?	and ten of the fraternities form the university of chicago interfraternity council
every may since 1987 , the university of chicago has held the university of chicago scavenger hunt , in which large teams of students compete to obtain notoriously esoteric items from a list .	in what month is the university 's scavenger hunt ?	in which large teams of students compete to obtain notoriously esoteric items from a list
every may since 1987 , the university of chicago has held the university of chicago scavenger hunt , in which large teams of students compete to obtain notoriously esoteric items from a list .	in what year did the scavenger hunt begin ?	in which large teams of students compete to obtain notoriously esoteric items from a list
since 1963 , the festival of the arts -lrb- fota -rrb- takes over campus for 7 -- 10 days of exhibitions and interactive artistic endeavors .	what does fota stand for ?	the festival of the arts -lrb- fota -rrb- takes over campus for 7 -- 10 days of exhibitions and interactive artistic endeavors
every january , the university holds a week-long winter festival , kuviasungnerk/kangeiko , which include early morning exercise routines and fitness workshops .	what is the name of the winter festival held in january that is based on fitness ?	which include early morning exercise routines and fitness workshops
the university also annually holds a summer carnival and concert called summer breeze that hosts outside musicians , and is home to doc films , a student film society founded in 1932 that screens films nightly at the university .	what is the name of the university 's summer festival ?	the university also annually holds a summer carnival and concert called summer breeze that hosts outside musicians
in business , notable alumni include microsoft ceo satya nadella , oracle corporation founder and the third richest man in america larry ellison , goldman sachs and mf global ceo as well as former governor of new jersey jon corzine , mckinsey & company founder and author of the first management accounting textbook james o. mckinsey , arley d. cathey , bloomberg l.p. ceo daniel doctoroff , credit suisse ceo brady dougan , morningstar , inc. founder and ceo joe mansueto , chicago cubs owner and chairman thomas s. ricketts , and nba commissioner adam silver .	what microsoft ceo is also an alumni of the university of chicago ?	mckinsey & company founder and author of the first management accounting textbook james o

notable alumni in the field of government and politics include the founder of modern community organizing saul alinsky , obama campaign advisor and top political advisor to president bill clinton david axelrod , attorney general and federal judge robert bork , attorney general ramsey clark , prohibition agent eliot ness , supreme court justice john paul stevens , prime minister of canada william lyon mackenzie king , 11th prime minister of poland marek belka , governor of the bank of japan masaaki shirakawa , the first female african-american senator carol moseley braun , united states senator from vermont and 2016 democratic presidential candidate bernie sanders , and former world bank president paul wolfowitz .	who is the founder of modern community organizing ?	notable alumni in the field of government and politics include the founder of modern community organizing saul alinsky

in literature , author of the new york times bestseller before i fall lauren oliver , pulitzer prize winning novelist philip roth , canadian-born pulitzer prize and nobel prize for literature winning writer saul bellow , political philosopher , literary critic and author of the new york times bestseller `` the closing of the american mind '' allan bloom , '' the good war '' author studs terkel , american writer , essayist , filmmaker , teacher , and political activist susan sontag , analytic philosopher and stanford university professor of comparative literature richard rorty , and american writer and satirist kurt vonnegut are notable alumni .	what alumni wrote `` the closing of the american mind '' ?	literary critic and author of the new york times bestseller `` the closing of the american mind '' allan bloom

in the arts and entertainment , minimalist composer philip glass , dancer , choreographer and leader in the field of dance anthropology katherine dunham , bungie founder and developer of the halo video game series alex seropian , serial host sarah koenig , actor ed asner , pulitzer prize for criticism winning film critic and the subject of the 2014 documentary film life itself roger ebert , director , writer , and comedian mike nichols , film director and screenwriter philip kaufman , and carl van vechten , photographer and writer , are graduates .	what minimalist composer is also a university graduate ?	pulitzer prize for criticism winning film critic and the subject of the 2014 documentary film life itself roger ebert

in science , alumni include astronomers carl sagan , a prominent contributor to the scientific research of extraterrestrial life , and edwin hubble , known for `` hubble 's law '' , nasa astronaut john m. grunsfeld , geneticist james watson , best known as one of the co-discoverers of the structure of dna , experimental physicist luis alvarez , popular environmentalist david suzuki , balloonist jeannette piccard , biologists ernest everett just and lynn margulis , computer scientist richard hamming , the creator of the hamming code , lithium-ion battery developer john b. goodenough , mathematician and fields medal recipient paul joseph cohen , and geochemist clair cameron patterson , who developed the uranium-lead dating method into lead-lead dating .	what astronomers is also a university alumni member ?	a prominent contributor to the scientific research of extraterrestrial life
in science , alumni include astronomers carl sagan , a prominent contributor to the scientific research of extraterrestrial life , and edwin hubble , known for `` hubble 's law '' , nasa astronaut john m. grunsfeld , geneticist james watson , best known as one of the co-discoverers of the structure of dna , experimental physicist luis alvarez , popular environmentalist david suzuki , balloonist jeannette piccard , biologists ernest everett just and lynn margulis , computer scientist richard hamming , the creator of the hamming code , lithium-ion battery developer john b. goodenough , mathematician and fields medal recipient paul joseph cohen , and geochemist clair cameron patterson , who developed the uranium-lead dating method into lead-lead dating .	what nasa astronaut is also a university alumni member ?	a prominent contributor to the scientific research of extraterrestrial life

in science , alumni include astronomers carl sagan , a prominent contributor to the scientific research of extraterrestrial life , and edwin hubble , known for `` hubble 's law '' , nasa astronaut john m. grunsfeld , geneticist james watson , best known as one of the co-discoverers of the structure of dna , experimental physicist luis alvarez , popular environmentalist david suzuki , balloonist jeannette piccard , biologists ernest everett just and lynn margulis , computer scientist richard hamming , the creator of the hamming code , lithium-ion battery developer john b. goodenough , mathematician and fields medal recipient paul joseph cohen , and geochemist clair cameron patterson , who developed the uranium-lead dating method into lead-lead dating .	who developed the lithium-ion battery ?	a prominent contributor to the scientific research of extraterrestrial life
in science , alumni include astronomers carl sagan , a prominent contributor to the scientific research of extraterrestrial life , and edwin hubble , known for `` hubble 's law '' , nasa astronaut john m. grunsfeld , geneticist james watson , best known as one of the co-discoverers of the structure of dna , experimental physicist luis alvarez , popular environmentalist david suzuki , balloonist jeannette piccard , biologists ernest everett just and lynn margulis , computer scientist richard hamming , the creator of the hamming code , lithium-ion battery developer john b. goodenough , mathematician and fields medal recipient paul joseph cohen , and geochemist clair cameron patterson , who developed the uranium-lead dating method into lead-lead dating .	what geochemist developed the uranium-lead dating method into lead-lead dating ?	a prominent contributor to the scientific research of extraterrestrial life
in economics , notable nobel memorial prize in economic sciences winners milton friedman , a major advisor to republican u.s. president ronald reagan and conservative british prime minister margaret thatcher , george stigler , nobel laureate and proponent of regulatory capture theory , gary becker , an important contributor to the family economics branch of economics , herbert a. simon , responsible for the modern interpretation of the concept of organizational decision-making , paul samuelson , the first american to win the nobel memorial prize in economic sciences , and eugene fama , known for his work on portfolio theory , asset pricing and stock market behaviour , are all graduates .	what nobel memorial prize in economic sciences winner is also a university alumni member ?	responsible for the modern interpretation of the concept of organizational decision-making
in economics , notable nobel memorial prize in economic sciences winners milton friedman , a major advisor to republican u.s. president ronald reagan and conservative british prime minister margaret thatcher , george stigler , nobel laureate and proponent of regulatory capture theory , gary becker , an important contributor to the family economics branch of economics , herbert a. simon , responsible for the modern interpretation of the concept of organizational decision-making , paul samuelson , the first american to win the nobel memorial prize in economic sciences , and eugene fama , known for his work on portfolio theory , asset pricing and stock market behaviour , are all graduates .	what british prime minister advisor is also a university alumni member ?	responsible for the modern interpretation of the concept of organizational decision-making

in economics , notable nobel memorial prize in economic sciences winners milton friedman , a major advisor to republican u.s. president ronald reagan and conservative british prime minister margaret thatcher , george stigler , nobel laureate and proponent of regulatory capture theory , gary becker , an important contributor to the family economics branch of economics , herbert a. simon , responsible for the modern interpretation of the concept of organizational decision-making , paul samuelson , the first american to win the nobel memorial prize in economic sciences , and eugene fama , known for his work on portfolio theory , asset pricing and stock market behaviour , are all graduates .	what university alumni member was known for his work on portfolio theory ?	responsible for the modern interpretation of the concept of organizational decision-making
other prominent alumni include anthropologists david graeber and donald johanson , who is best known for discovering the fossil of a female hominid australopithecine known as `` lucy '' in the afar triangle region , psychologist john b. watson , american psychologist who established the psychological school of behaviorism , communication theorist harold innis , chess grandmaster samuel reshevsky , and conservative international relations scholar and white house coordinator of security planning for the national security council samuel p. huntington .	what anthropologists are also university alumni members ?	and conservative international relations scholar and white house coordinator of security planning for the national security council samuel p

notable faculty in physics have included the speed of light calculator a. a. michelson , elementary charge calculator robert a. millikan , discoverer of the compton effect arthur h. compton , the creator of the first nuclear reactor enrico fermi , `` the father of the hydrogen bomb '' edward teller , `` one of the most brilliant and productive experimental physicists of the twentieth century '' luis walter alvarez , murray gell-mann who introduced the quark , second female nobel laureate maria goeppert-mayer , the youngest american winner of the nobel prize tsung-dao lee , and astrophysicist subrahmanyan chandrasekhar .	who calculated the speed of light ?	`` one of the most brilliant and productive experimental physicists of the twentieth century '' luis walter alvarez

the yuan dynasty -lrb- chinese : 元朝 ; pinyin : yuán cháo -rrb- , officially the great yuan -lrb- chinese : 大元 ; pinyin : dà yuán ; mongolian : yehe yuan ulus -lsb- a -rsb- -rrb- , was the empire or ruling dynasty of china established by kublai khan , leader of the mongolian borjigin clan .	what is the chinese name for the yuan dynasty ?	was the empire or ruling dynasty of china established by kublai khan
the yuan dynasty -lrb- chinese : 元朝 ; pinyin : yuán cháo -rrb- , officially the great yuan -lrb- chinese : 大元 ; pinyin : dà yuán ; mongolian : yehe yuan ulus -lsb- a -rsb- -rrb- , was the empire or ruling dynasty of china established by kublai khan , leader of the mongolian borjigin clan .	what is the yuan dynasty 's official name ?	was the empire or ruling dynasty of china established by kublai khan

the yuan dynasty -lrb- chinese : 元朝 ; pinyin : yuán cháo -rrb- , officially the great yuan -lrb- chinese : 大元 ; pinyin : dà yuán ; mongolian : yehe yuan ulus -lsb- a -rsb- -rrb- , was the empire or ruling dynasty of china established by kublai khan , leader of the mongolian borjigin clan .	who led the mongolian borjigin clan ?	was the empire or ruling dynasty of china established by kublai khan
although the mongols had ruled territories including today 's north china for decades , it was not until 1271 that kublai khan officially proclaimed the dynasty in the traditional chinese style .	when did khan formally declare the yuan dynasty ?	it was not until 1271 that kublai khan officially proclaimed the dynasty in the traditional chinese style
the yuan dynasty is considered both a successor to the mongol empire and an imperial chinese dynasty .	what non-chinese empire did the yuan dynasty succeed ?	the yuan dynasty is considered both a successor to the mongol empire and an imperial chinese dynasty
in official chinese histories , the yuan dynasty bore the mandate of heaven , following the song dynasty and preceding the ming dynasty .	what dynasty came before the yuan ?	following the song dynasty and preceding the ming dynasty

the dynasty was established by kublai khan , yet he placed his grandfather genghis khan on the imperial records as the official founder of the dynasty as taizu .	who was kublai khan 's grandfather ?	yet he placed his grandfather genghis khan on the imperial records as the official founder of the dynasty as taizu
in 1271 , kublai khan imposed the name great yuan -lrb- chinese : 大元 ; pinyin : dà yuán ; wade -- giles : ta-yüan -rrb- , establishing the yuan dynasty .	when did khan establish the great yuan ?	kublai khan imposed the name great yuan -lrb- chinese : 大元
`` dà yuán '' -lrb- 大元 -rrb- is from the sentence '' 大哉乾元 '' -lrb- dà zai qián yuán / `` great is qián , the primal '' -rrb- in the commentaries on the classic of changes -lrb- i ching -rrb- section regarding qián -lrb- 乾 -rrb- .	what writing inspired the name great yuan ?	the primal '' -rrb- in the commentaries on the classic of changes -lrb- i ching -rrb- section regarding qián -lrb- 乾 -rrb-
the counterpart in mongolian language was dai ön ulus , also rendered as ikh yuan üls or yekhe yuan ulus .	what was the yuan dynasty called in mongolian ?	the counterpart in mongolian language was dai ön ulus
`` great mongol state '' -rrb- , resulting in dai ön yeke mongghul ulus -lrb- mongolian script : -rrb- , meaning `` great yuan great mongol state '' .	what does yeke mongghul ulus mean ?	resulting in dai ön yeke mongghul ulus -lrb- mongolian script : -rrb-
furthermore , the yuan is sometimes known as the `` empire of the great khan '' or `` khanate of the great khan '' , which particularly appeared on some yuan maps , since yuan emperors held the nominal title of great khan .	what nominal title did yuan emperors have ?	the yuan is sometimes known as the `` empire of the great khan '' or `` khanate of the great khan ''

under the reign of genghis ' third son , ögedei khan , the mongols destroyed the weakened jin dynasty in 1234 , conquering most of northern china .	who was genghis 's 3rd son ?	the mongols destroyed the weakened jin dynasty in 1234
möngke khan succeeded ögedei 's son , güyük , as great khan in 1251 .	when did mongke khan become great khan ?	möngke khan succeeded ögedei 's son
ögedei offered his nephew kublai a position in xingzhou , hebei .	what was kublai khan 's relation to ogedei khan ?	ögedei offered his nephew kublai a position in xingzhou
many han chinese and khitan defected to the mongols to fight against the jin .	who did the han chinese want to help the mongols fight ?	many han chinese and khitan defected to the mongols to fight against the jin
two han chinese leaders , shi tianze , liu heima -lrb- 劉黑馬 , liu ni -rrb- , and the khitan xiao zhala -lrb- 蕭札剌 -rrb- defected and commanded the 3 tumens in the mongol army .	what khitan leader defected to the mongols ?	and the khitan xiao zhala -lrb- 蕭札剌 -rrb- defected and commanded the 3 tumens in the mongol army

there were 4 han tumens and 3 khitan tumens , with each tumen consisting of 10,000 troops .	how many soldiers were in each tumen ?	there were 4 han tumens and 3 khitan tumens

he bolstered his popularity among his subjects by modeling his government on the bureaucracy of traditional chinese dynasties and adopting the chinese era name of zhongtong .	what chinese era name did kublai adopt ?	he bolstered his popularity among his subjects by modeling his government on the bureaucracy of traditional chinese dynasties and adopting the chinese era name of zhongtong

kublai 's government after 1262 was a compromise between preserving mongol interests in china and satisfying the demands of his chinese subjects .	what did kublai 's government have to balance between ?	kublai 's government after 1262 was a compromise between preserving mongol interests in china and satisfying the demands of his chinese subjects
he restored the imperial secretariat and left the local administrative structure of past chinese dynasties unchanged .	what administrative division did kublai leave unmodified ?	he restored the imperial secretariat and left the local administrative structure of past chinese dynasties unchanged
however , kublai rejected plans to revive the confucian imperial examinations and divided yuan society into three , later four , classes with the han chinese occupying the lowest rank .	who would have been the lowest-ranked class ?	kublai rejected plans to revive the confucian imperial examinations and divided yuan society into three

he instituted the reforms proposed by his chinese advisers by centralizing the bureaucracy , expanding the circulation of paper money , and maintaining the traditional monopolies on salt and iron .	what natural resources did the chinese government have a monopoly on ?	he instituted the reforms proposed by his chinese advisers by centralizing the bureaucracy

during the southern song dynasty the descendant of confucius at qufu , the duke yansheng kong duanyou fled south with the song emperor to quzhou , while the newly established jin dynasty -lrb- 1115 -- 1234 -rrb- in the north appointed kong duanyou 's brother kong duancao who remained in qufu as duke yansheng .	who did duke yansheng kong duanyou flee with ?	while the newly established jin dynasty -lrb- 1115 -- 1234 -rrb- in the north appointed kong duanyou 's brother kong duancao who remained in qufu as duke yansheng

the system of bureaucracy created by kublai khan reflected various cultures in the empire , including that of the han chinese , khitans , jurchens , mongols , and tibetan buddhists .	what cultures were part of kublai 's administration ?	the system of bureaucracy created by kublai khan reflected various cultures in the empire
the chinese-style elements of the bureaucracy mainly came from the native tang , song , as well as khitan liao and jurchen jin dynasties .	what dynasties inspired the chinese-like elements of kublai 's government ?	the chinese-style elements of the bureaucracy mainly came from the native tang
chinese advisers such as liu bingzhong and yao shu gave strong influence to kublai 's early court , and the central government administration was established within the first decade of kublai 's reign .	who were two of kublai 's chinese advisers ?	and the central government administration was established within the first decade of kublai 's reign
this government adopted the traditional chinese tripartite division of authority among civil , military , and censorial offices , including the central secretariat -lrb- zhongshu sheng -rrb- to manage civil affairs , the privy council -lrb- chinese : 樞密院 -rrb- to manage military affairs , and the censorate to conduct internal surveillance and inspection .	what kind of division of power did kublai 's government have ?	this government adopted the traditional chinese tripartite division of authority among civil

while the existence of these central government departments and the six ministries -lrb- which had been introduced since the sui and tang dynasties -rrb- gave a sinicized image in the yuan administration , the actual functions of these ministries also reflected how mongolian priorities and policies reshaped and redirected those institutions .	when had the six ministries existed ?	while the existence of these central government departments and the six ministries -lrb- which had been introduced since the sui and tang dynasties -rrb- gave a sinicized image in the yuan administration

seeing this as damaging to the mongol nation , kublai in 1291 forbade the sale abroad of mongols .	when did kublai ban the international mongol slave trade ?	kublai in 1291 forbade the sale abroad of mongols
the average mongol garrison family of the yuan dynasty seems to have lived a life of decaying rural leisure , with income from the harvests of their chinese tenants eaten up by costs of equipping and dispatching men for their tours of duty .	how were the mongol garrison families earning money ?	with income from the harvests of their chinese tenants eaten up by costs of equipping and dispatching men for their tours of duty
in the china of the yuan , or mongol era , various important developments in the arts occurred or continued in their development , including the areas of painting , mathematics , calligraphy , poetry , and theater , with many great artists and writers being famous today .	what type of arts flourished in the yuan ?	various important developments in the arts occurred or continued in their development
due to the coming together of painting , poetry , and calligraphy at this time many of the artists practicing these different pursuits were the same individuals , though perhaps more famed for one area of their achievements than others .	which arts were often practiced together by the same artists ?	and calligraphy at this time many of the artists practicing these different pursuits were the same individuals
often in terms of the further development of landscape painting as well as the classical joining together of the arts of painting , poetry , and calligraphy , the song dynasty and the yuan dynasty are linked together .	what dynasty shared artistic inspiration with the yuan ?	often in terms of the further development of landscape painting as well as the classical joining together of the arts of painting
in yuan poetry , the main development was the qu , which was used among other poetic forms by most of the famous yuan poets .	what form of poetry was developed in the yuan ?	which was used among other poetic forms by most of the famous yuan poets

however , unlike the western khanates , the yuan dynasty never converted to islam .	which khanates had converted to islam ?	the yuan dynasty never converted to islam
instead , kublai khan , the founder of the yuan dynasty , favored buddhism , especially the tibetan variants .	which religion did kublai prefer ?	especially the tibetan variants
as a result , tibetan buddhism was established as the de facto state religion .	what was the yuan 's unofficial state religion ?	tibetan buddhism was established as the de facto state religion
the top-level department and government agency known as the bureau of buddhist and tibetan affairs -lrb- xuanzheng yuan -rrb- was set up in khanbaliq -lrb- modern beijing -rrb- to supervise buddhist monks throughout the empire .	what government agency supervised buddhist monks ?	the top-level department and government agency known as the bureau of buddhist and tibetan affairs -lrb- xuanzheng yuan -rrb- was set up in khanbaliq -lrb- modern beijing -rrb- to supervise buddhist monks throughout the empire

the mathematician zhu shijie -lrb- 1249 -- 1314 -rrb- solved simultaneous equations with up to four unknowns using a rectangular array of coefficients , equivalent to modern matrices .	when was zhu shijie born ?	the mathematician zhu shijie -lrb- 1249 -- 1314 -rrb- solved simultaneous equations with up to four unknowns using a rectangular array of coefficients

healers were divided into non-mongol physicians called otachi and traditional mongol shamans .	who were otachi ?	healers were divided into non-mongol physicians called otachi and traditional mongol shamans

confucian scholars were attracted to the medical profession because it ensured a high income and medical ethics were compatible with confucian virtues .	why did confucians like the medical field ?	confucian scholars were attracted to the medical profession because it ensured a high income and medical ethics were compatible with confucian virtues
all four schools were based on the same intellectual foundation , but advocated different theoretical approaches toward medicine .	how many schools of medicine were recognized in china ?	all four schools were based on the same intellectual foundation
the chinese medical tradition of the yuan had `` four great schools '' that the yuan inherited from the jin dynasty .	how did the yuan come to have the 4 schools of medicine ?	the chinese medical tradition of the yuan had `` four great schools '' that the yuan inherited from the jin dynasty
chinese physicians were brought along military campaigns by the mongols as they expanded towards the west .	how did chinese medicine spread ?	chinese physicians were brought along military campaigns by the mongols as they expanded towards the west
chinese medical techniques such as acupuncture , moxibustion , pulse diagnosis , and various herbal drugs and elixirs were transmitted westward to the middle east and the rest of the empire .	what techniques did chinese medicine include ?	and various herbal drugs and elixirs were transmitted westward to the middle east and the rest of the empire

chao were made from the bark of mulberry trees .	what were chao made out of ?	chao were made from the bark of mulberry trees

although the traditional chinese elite were not given their share of power , the mongols and the semuren -lrb- various allied groups from central asia and the western end of the empire -rrb- largely remained strangers to the mainstream chinese culture , and this dichotomy gave the yuan regime a somewhat strong `` colonial '' coloration .	who were the semuren ?	the mongols and the semuren -lrb- various allied groups from central asia and the western end of the empire -rrb- largely remained strangers to the mainstream chinese culture

the historian frederick w. mote wrote that the usage of the term `` social classes '' for this system was misleading and that the position of people within the four-class system was not an indication of their actual social power and wealth , but just entailed `` degrees of privilege '' to which they were entitled institutionally and legally , so a person 's standing within the classes was not a guarantee of their standing , since there were rich and well socially standing chinese while there were less rich mongol and semu than there were mongol and semu who lived in poverty and were ill treated .	who thought that the yuan 's social class system should n't be called social classes ?	mote wrote that the usage of the term `` social classes '' for this system was misleading and that the position of people within the four-class system was not an indication of their actual social power and wealth

when the mongols placed the uighurs of the kingdom of qocho over the koreans at the court the korean king objected , then the mongol emperor kublai khan rebuked the korean king , saying that the uighur king of qocho was ranked higher than the karluk kara-khanid ruler , who in turn was ranked higher than the korean king , who was ranked last , because the uighurs surrendered to the mongols first , the karluks surrendered after the uighurs , and the koreans surrendered last , and that the uighurs surrendered peacefully without violently resisting .	who did the mongols give control of korea ?	when the mongols placed the uighurs of the kingdom of qocho over the koreans at the court the korean king objected

the central region , consisting of present-day hebei , shandong , shanxi , the south-eastern part of present-day inner mongolia and the henan areas to the north of the yellow river , was considered the most important region of the dynasty and directly governed by the central secretariat -lrb- or zhongshu sheng -rrb- at khanbaliq -lrb- modern beijing -rrb- ; similarly , another top-level administrative department called the bureau of buddhist and tibetan affairs -lrb- or xuanzheng yuan -rrb- held administrative rule over the whole of modern-day tibet and a part of sichuan , qinghai and kashmir .	what region of china is hebei part of ?	another top-level administrative department called the bureau of buddhist and tibetan affairs -lrb- or xuanzheng yuan -rrb- held administrative rule over the whole of modern-day tibet and a part of sichuan

kenya -lrb- / ˈkɛnjə / ; locally -lsb- ˈkɛɲa -rsb- -lrb- listen -rrb- -rrb- , officially the republic of kenya , is a country in africa and a founding member of the east african community -lrb- eac -rrb- .	what is kenya a founding member of ?	is a country in africa and a founding member of the east african community -lrb- eac -rrb-
its capital and largest city is nairobi .	what is the capitol of kenya ?	its capital and largest city is nairobi
it is bordered by tanzania to the south , uganda to the west , south sudan to the north-west , ethiopia to the north and somalia to the north-east .	what country boarders the south of kenya ?	ethiopia to the north and somalia to the north-east

kenya has a warm and humid tropical climate on its indian ocean coastline .	what type of climate does kenya have ?	kenya has a warm and humid tropical climate on its indian ocean coastline
the climate is cooler in the savannah grasslands around the capital city , nairobi , and especially closer to mount kenya , which has snow permanently on its peaks .	how is the climate near the savannah grasslands ?	the climate is cooler in the savannah grasslands around the capital city

two million wildebeest migrate a distance of 2,900 kilometres -lrb- 1,802 mi -rrb- from the serengeti in neighbouring tanzania to the masai mara in kenya , in a constant clockwise fashion , searching for food and water supplies .	how far do the wildebeest migrate searching for food and water ?	802 mi -rrb- from the serengeti in neighbouring tanzania to the masai mara in kenya

industrial activity , concentrated around the three largest urban centres , nairobi , mombasa and kisumu , is dominated by food-processing industries such as grain milling , beer production , and sugarcane crushing , and the fabrication of consumer goods , e.g. , vehicles from kits .	what are the three largest urban areas in kenya ?	is dominated by food-processing industries such as grain milling

between 1964 and 1985 , the 7 -- 4 -- 2 -- 3 system was adopted -- seven years of primary , four years of lower secondary , two years of upper secondary , and three years of university .	what system was adopted for education ?	the 7 -- 4 -- 2 -- 3 system was adopted -- seven years of primary
in 1981 , the presidential working party on the second university was commissioned to look at both the possibilities of setting up a second university in kenya as well as the reforming of the entire education system .	what was the presidential working party on the second university commissioned to do ?	the presidential working party on the second university was commissioned to look at both the possibilities of setting up a second university in kenya as well as the reforming of the entire education system
the committee recommended that the 7 -- 4 -- 2 -- 3 system be changed to an 8 -- 4 -- 4 system -lrb- eight years in primary , four years in secondary , and four years in university education -rrb- .	what did they want the educational system to be ?	the committee recommended that the 7 -- 4 -- 2 -- 3 system be changed to an 8 -- 4 -- 4 system -lrb- eight years in primary

basic formal education starts at age six years and lasts 12 years comprising eight years in primary school and four years in high school or secondary school .	what age does basic education start ?	basic formal education starts at age six years and lasts 12 years comprising eight years in primary school and four years in high school or secondary school

primary school is free in public schools and those who exit at this level can join a vocational youth/village polytechnic or make their own arrangements for an apprenticeship program and learn a trade such as tailoring , carpentry , motor vehicle repair , brick-laying and masonry for about two years .	what do students do after primary school ?	primary school is free in public schools and those who exit at this level can join a vocational youth/village polytechnic or make their own arrangements for an apprenticeship program and learn a trade such as tailoring

kenyans generally have three meals in a day -- breakfast in the morning -lrb- kiamsha kinywa -rrb- , lunch in the afternoon -lrb- chakula cha mchana -rrb- and supper in the evening -lrb- chakula cha jioni or known simply as `` chajio '' -rrb- .	how many meals a day do normal kenyans eat ?	lunch in the afternoon -lrb- chakula cha mchana -rrb- and supper in the evening -lrb- chakula cha jioni or known simply as `` chajio '' -rrb-
in between , they have the 10 o'clock tea -lrb- chai ya saa nne -rrb- and 4 pm tea -lrb- chai ya saa kumi -rrb- .	what time do they normally have tea ?	they have the 10 o'clock tea -lrb- chai ya saa nne -rrb- and 4 pm tea -lrb- chai ya saa kumi -rrb-
breakfast is usually tea or porridge with bread , chapati , mahamri , boiled sweet potatoes or yams .	what are some normal breakfast foods ?	breakfast is usually tea or porridge with bread
ugali with vegetables , sour milk , meat , fish or any other stew is generally eaten by much of the population for lunch or supper .	what is normally eaten for lunch and supper ?	fish or any other stew is generally eaten by much of the population for lunch or supper
the intergovernmental panel on climate change -lrb- ipcc -rrb- is a scientific intergovernmental body under the auspices of the united nations , set up at the request of member governments .	what organization is the ipcc a part of ?	the intergovernmental panel on climate change -lrb- ipcc -rrb- is a scientific intergovernmental body under the auspices of the united nations
it was first established in 1988 by two united nations organizations , the world meteorological organization -lrb- wmo -rrb- and the united nations environment programme -lrb- unep -rrb- , and later endorsed by the united nations general assembly through resolution 43/53 .	what un organizations established the ipcc ?	the world meteorological organization -lrb- wmo -rrb- and the united nations environment programme -lrb- unep -rrb-
the ultimate objective of the unfccc is to `` stabilize greenhouse gas concentrations in the atmosphere at a level that would prevent dangerous anthropogenic -lsb- i.e. , human-induced -rsb- interference with the climate system '' .	what does the un want to stabilize ?	the ultimate objective of the unfccc is to `` stabilize greenhouse gas concentrations in the atmosphere at a level that would prevent dangerous anthropogenic -lsb- i
the ipcc produces reports that support the united nations framework convention on climate change -lrb- unfccc -rrb- , which is the main international treaty on climate change .	what is the un 's climate change treaty ?	the ipcc produces reports that support the united nations framework convention on climate change -lrb- unfccc -rrb-
it was first established in 1988 by two united nations organizations , the world meteorological organization -lrb- wmo -rrb- and the united nations environment programme -lrb- unep -rrb- , and later endorsed by the united nations general assembly through resolution 43/53 .	what un resolution endorsed the ipcc ?	the world meteorological organization -lrb- wmo -rrb- and the united nations environment programme -lrb- unep -rrb-

the ipcc receives funding through the ipcc trust fund , established in 1989 by the united nations environment programme -lrb- unep -rrb- and the world meteorological organization -lrb- wmo -rrb- , costs of the secretary and of housing the secretariat are provided by the wmo , while unep meets the cost of the depute secretary .	when was the ipcc trust fund founded ?	established in 1989 by the united nations environment programme -lrb- unep -rrb- and the world meteorological organization -lrb- wmo -rrb-
the ipcc receives funding through the ipcc trust fund , established in 1989 by the united nations environment programme -lrb- unep -rrb- and the world meteorological organization -lrb- wmo -rrb- , costs of the secretary and of housing the secretariat are provided by the wmo , while unep meets the cost of the depute secretary .	who started the ipcc trust fund ?	established in 1989 by the united nations environment programme -lrb- unep -rrb- and the world meteorological organization -lrb- wmo -rrb-
the ipcc receives funding through the ipcc trust fund , established in 1989 by the united nations environment programme -lrb- unep -rrb- and the world meteorological organization -lrb- wmo -rrb- , costs of the secretary and of housing the secretariat are provided by the wmo , while unep meets the cost of the depute secretary .	who funds the ipcc 's deputy secretary ?	established in 1989 by the united nations environment programme -lrb- unep -rrb- and the world meteorological organization -lrb- wmo -rrb-
the organisation is required to comply with the financial regulations and rules of the wmo .	what rules does the ipcc have to follow ?	the organisation is required to comply with the financial regulations and rules of the wmo
the ipcc receives funding through the ipcc trust fund , established in 1989 by the united nations environment programme -lrb- unep -rrb- and the world meteorological organization -lrb- wmo -rrb- , costs of the secretary and of housing the secretariat are provided by the wmo , while unep meets the cost of the depute secretary .	who funds the ipcc 's secretary ?	established in 1989 by the united nations environment programme -lrb- unep -rrb- and the world meteorological organization -lrb- wmo -rrb-
the ipcc does not carry out research nor does it monitor climate related data .	what does the ipcc not do ?	the ipcc does not carry out research nor does it monitor climate related data
lead authors of ipcc reports assess the available information about climate change based on published sources .	where do ipcc reports get their information ?	lead authors of ipcc reports assess the available information about climate change based on published sources
authors may refer to non-peer-reviewed sources -lrb- the `` grey literature '' -rrb- , provided that they are of sufficient quality .	what is ` grey literature ' ?	authors may refer to non-peer-reviewed sources -lrb- the `` grey literature '' -rrb-
examples of non-peer-reviewed sources include model results , reports from government agencies and non-governmental organizations , and industry journals .	what kind of non-peer-reviewed sources does the ipcc use ?	reports from government agencies and non-governmental organizations
a chapter typically has two `` coordinating lead authors '' , ten to fifteen `` lead authors '' , and a somewhat larger number of `` contributing authors '' .	how many coordinating lead authors does an ipcc report chapter have ?	a chapter typically has two `` coordinating lead authors ''

the coordinating lead authors are responsible for assembling the contributions of the other authors , ensuring that they meet stylistic and formatting requirements , and reporting to the working group chairs .	who assembles the authors ' contributions ?	the coordinating lead authors are responsible for assembling the contributions of the other authors

chloroplasts ' main role is to conduct photosynthesis , where the photosynthetic pigment chlorophyll captures the energy from sunlight and converts it and stores it in the energy-storage molecules atp and nadph while freeing oxygen from water .	what is the primary purpose of chloroplasts ?	where the photosynthetic pigment chlorophyll captures the energy from sunlight and converts it and stores it in the energy-storage molecules atp and nadph while freeing oxygen from water
chloroplasts ' main role is to conduct photosynthesis , where the photosynthetic pigment chlorophyll captures the energy from sunlight and converts it and stores it in the energy-storage molecules atp and nadph while freeing oxygen from water .	what does atp store ?	where the photosynthetic pigment chlorophyll captures the energy from sunlight and converts it and stores it in the energy-storage molecules atp and nadph while freeing oxygen from water
chloroplasts ' main role is to conduct photosynthesis , where the photosynthetic pigment chlorophyll captures the energy from sunlight and converts it and stores it in the energy-storage molecules atp and nadph while freeing oxygen from water .	what does nadph store ?	where the photosynthetic pigment chlorophyll captures the energy from sunlight and converts it and stores it in the energy-storage molecules atp and nadph while freeing oxygen from water
they then use the atp and nadph to make organic molecules from carbon dioxide in a process known as the calvin cycle .	what is the process of turning co2 into organic molecules called ?	they then use the atp and nadph to make organic molecules from carbon dioxide in a process known as the calvin cycle
the number of chloroplasts per cell varies from 1 in algae up to 100 in plants like arabidopsis and wheat .	how many chloroplasts per cell does algae have ?	the number of chloroplasts per cell varies from 1 in algae up to 100 in plants like arabidopsis and wheat
chloroplasts are highly dynamic -- they circulate and are moved around within plant cells , and occasionally pinch in two to reproduce .	how do chloroplasts reproduce ?	chloroplasts are highly dynamic -- they circulate and are moved around within plant cells
their behavior is strongly influenced by environmental factors like light color and intensity .	what influences chloroplasts ' behavior ?	their behavior is strongly influenced by environmental factors like light color and intensity
chloroplasts , like mitochondria , contain their own dna , which is thought to be inherited from their ancestor -- a photosynthetic cyanobacterium that was engulfed by an early eukaryotic cell .	how are chloroplasts similar to mitochondria ?	which is thought to be inherited from their ancestor -- a photosynthetic cyanobacterium that was engulfed by an early eukaryotic cell
chloroplasts , like mitochondria , contain their own dna , which is thought to be inherited from their ancestor -- a photosynthetic cyanobacterium that was engulfed by an early eukaryotic cell .	what was the ancestor of chloroplasts ?	which is thought to be inherited from their ancestor -- a photosynthetic cyanobacterium that was engulfed by an early eukaryotic cell
chloroplasts can not be made by the plant cell and must be inherited by each daughter cell during cell division .	how do plants get chloroplasts ?	chloroplasts can not be made by the plant cell and must be inherited by each daughter cell during cell division
chloroplasts are only found in plants and algae .	which organisms have chloroplasts ?	chloroplasts are only found in plants and algae
this origin of chloroplasts was first suggested by the russian biologist konstantin mereschkowski in 1905 after andreas schimper observed in 1883 that chloroplasts closely resemble cyanobacteria .	what nationality was konstantin mereschkowski ?	this origin of chloroplasts was first suggested by the russian biologist konstantin mereschkowski in 1905 after andreas schimper observed in 1883 that chloroplasts closely resemble cyanobacteria

cyanobacteria are considered the ancestors of chloroplasts .	what are chloroplasts descended from ?	cyanobacteria are considered the ancestors of chloroplasts
they are sometimes called blue-green algae even though they are prokaryotes .	what type of organism are cyanobacteria ?	they are sometimes called blue-green algae even though they are prokaryotes
they are a diverse phylum of bacteria capable of carrying out photosynthesis , and are gram-negative , meaning that they have two cell membranes .	what does ` gram-negative ' mean ?	they are a diverse phylum of bacteria capable of carrying out photosynthesis
cyanobacteria also contain a peptidoglycan cell wall , which is thicker than in other gram-negative bacteria , and which is located between their two cell membranes .	what kind of cell wall do cyanobacteria have ?	which is thicker than in other gram-negative bacteria
they are sometimes called blue-green algae even though they are prokaryotes .	how are cyanobacteria sometimes wrongly described ?	they are sometimes called blue-green algae even though they are prokaryotes
somewhere around a billion years ago , a free-living cyanobacterium entered an early eukaryotic cell , either as food or as an internal parasite , but managed to escape the phagocytic vacuole it was contained in .	what kind of cell did cynaobacteria enter long ago ?	but managed to escape the phagocytic vacuole it was contained in
somewhere around a billion years ago , a free-living cyanobacterium entered an early eukaryotic cell , either as food or as an internal parasite , but managed to escape the phagocytic vacuole it was contained in .	how long ago did cyanobacteria enter a cell ?	but managed to escape the phagocytic vacuole it was contained in
the two innermost lipid-bilayer membranes that surround all chloroplasts correspond to the outer and inner membranes of the ancestral cyanobacterium 's gram negative cell wall , and not the phagosomal membrane from the host , which was probably lost .	what surrounds chloroplasts ?	the two innermost lipid-bilayer membranes that surround all chloroplasts correspond to the outer and inner membranes of the ancestral cyanobacterium 's gram negative cell wall

over time , the cyanobacterium was assimilated , and many of its genes were lost or transferred to the nucleus of the host .	what happened when cyanobacteria was assimilated ?	and many of its genes were lost or transferred to the nucleus of the host
these chloroplasts , which can be traced back directly to a cyanobacterial ancestor , are known as primary plastids -lrb- `` plastid '' in this context means almost the same thing as chloroplast -rrb- .	what does ` plastid ' mean ?	are known as primary plastids -lrb- `` plastid '' in this context means almost the same thing as chloroplast -rrb-
all primary chloroplasts belong to one of three chloroplast lineages -- the glaucophyte chloroplast lineage , the rhodophyte , or red algal chloroplast lineage , or the chloroplastidan , or green chloroplast lineage .	how many chloroplast lineages are there ?	all primary chloroplasts belong to one of three chloroplast lineages -- the glaucophyte chloroplast lineage
all primary chloroplasts belong to one of three chloroplast lineages -- the glaucophyte chloroplast lineage , the rhodophyte , or red algal chloroplast lineage , or the chloroplastidan , or green chloroplast lineage .	what does rhodophyte mean ?	all primary chloroplasts belong to one of three chloroplast lineages -- the glaucophyte chloroplast lineage
all primary chloroplasts belong to one of three chloroplast lineages -- the glaucophyte chloroplast lineage , the rhodophyte , or red algal chloroplast lineage , or the chloroplastidan , or green chloroplast lineage .	what does chloroplastidan mean ?	all primary chloroplasts belong to one of three chloroplast lineages -- the glaucophyte chloroplast lineage
the second two are the largest , and the green chloroplast lineage is the one that contains the land plants .	which lineage includes land plants ?	and the green chloroplast lineage is the one that contains the land plants

rhodoplasts have chlorophyll a and phycobilins for photosynthetic pigments ; the phycobilin phycoerytherin is responsible for giving many red algae their distinctive red color .	what kinds of pigments do rhodoplasts have ?	the phycobilin phycoerytherin is responsible for giving many red algae their distinctive red color
rhodoplasts have a double membrane with an intermembrane space and phycobilin pigments organized into phycobilisomes on the thylakoid membranes , preventing their thylakoids from stacking .	what are rhodoplasts ' phycobilin pigments combined into ?	rhodoplasts have a double membrane with an intermembrane space and phycobilin pigments organized into phycobilisomes on the thylakoid membranes
rhodoplasts have chlorophyll a and phycobilins for photosynthetic pigments ; the phycobilin phycoerytherin is responsible for giving many red algae their distinctive red color .	what makes red algae red ?	the phycobilin phycoerytherin is responsible for giving many red algae their distinctive red color
the red phycoerytherin pigment is an adaptation to help red algae catch more sunlight in deep water -- as such , some red algae that live in shallow water have less phycoerytherin in their rhodoplasts , and can appear more greenish .	what is the benefit of red algae being red ?	the red phycoerytherin pigment is an adaptation to help red algae catch more sunlight in deep water -- as such
rhodoplasts synthesize a form of starch called floridean , which collects into granules outside the rhodoplast , in the cytoplasm of the red alga .	what is floridean ?	rhodoplasts synthesize a form of starch called floridean
they differ from glaucophyte and red algal chloroplasts in that they have lost their phycobilisomes , and contain chlorophyll b instead .	what do red algal chloroplasts have that green chloroplasts do n't ?	they differ from glaucophyte and red algal chloroplasts in that they have lost their phycobilisomes
most green chloroplasts are -lrb- obviously -rrb- green , though some are n't , like some forms of hæmatococcus pluvialis , due to accessory pigments that override the chlorophylls ' green colors .	why are n't some forms of hæmatococcus pluvialis green ?	due to accessory pigments that override the chlorophylls ' green colors

while primary chloroplasts have a double membrane from their cyanobacterial ancestor , secondary chloroplasts have additional membranes outside of the original two , as a result of the secondary endosymbiotic event , when a nonphotosynthetic eukaryote engulfed a chloroplast-containing alga but failed to digest it -- much like the cyanobacterium at the beginning of this story .	what kind of membrane do primary chloroplasts have ?	when a nonphotosynthetic eukaryote engulfed a chloroplast-containing alga but failed to digest it -- much like the cyanobacterium at the beginning of this story
while primary chloroplasts have a double membrane from their cyanobacterial ancestor , secondary chloroplasts have additional membranes outside of the original two , as a result of the secondary endosymbiotic event , when a nonphotosynthetic eukaryote engulfed a chloroplast-containing alga but failed to digest it -- much like the cyanobacterium at the beginning of this story .	what differs about secondary chloroplasts ' membranes ?	when a nonphotosynthetic eukaryote engulfed a chloroplast-containing alga but failed to digest it -- much like the cyanobacterium at the beginning of this story
while primary chloroplasts have a double membrane from their cyanobacterial ancestor , secondary chloroplasts have additional membranes outside of the original two , as a result of the secondary endosymbiotic event , when a nonphotosynthetic eukaryote engulfed a chloroplast-containing alga but failed to digest it -- much like the cyanobacterium at the beginning of this story .	what was the secondary endosymbiotic event ?	when a nonphotosynthetic eukaryote engulfed a chloroplast-containing alga but failed to digest it -- much like the cyanobacterium at the beginning of this story
the engulfed alga was broken down , leaving only its chloroplast , and sometimes its cell membrane and nucleus , forming a chloroplast with three or four membranes -- the two cyanobacterial membranes , sometimes the eaten alga 's cell membrane , and the phagosomal vacuole from the host 's cell membrane .	what additional membranes do secondary chloroplasts have ?	forming a chloroplast with three or four membranes -- the two cyanobacterial membranes

plant chloroplasts provide plant cells with many important things besides sugar , and apicoplasts are no different -- they synthesize fatty acids , isopentenyl pyrophosphate , iron-sulfur clusters , and carry out part of the heme pathway .	what do apicoplasts synthesize ?	plant chloroplasts provide plant cells with many important things besides sugar
this makes the apicoplast an attractive target for drugs to cure apicomplexan-related diseases .	what kind of diseases do drugs target apicoplasts for ?	this makes the apicoplast an attractive target for drugs to cure apicomplexan-related diseases
the most important apicoplast function is isopentenyl pyrophosphate synthesis -- in fact , apicomplexans die when something interferes with this apicoplast function , and when apicomplexans are grown in an isopentenyl pyrophosphate-rich medium , they dump the organelle .	what is the most important thing apicoplasts do ?	the most important apicoplast function is isopentenyl pyrophosphate synthesis -- in fact

chloroplasts have their own dna , often abbreviated as ctdna , or cpdna .	what is chloroplast dna abbreviated as ?	chloroplasts have their own dna
it is also known as the plastome .	what is a synonym for chloroplast dna ?	it is also known as the plastome
its existence was first proved in 1962 , and first sequenced in 1986 -- when two japanese research teams sequenced the chloroplast dna of liverwort and tobacco .	when was the plastome discovered ?	and first sequenced in 1986 -- when two japanese research teams sequenced the chloroplast dna of liverwort and tobacco
its existence was first proved in 1962 , and first sequenced in 1986 -- when two japanese research teams sequenced the chloroplast dna of liverwort and tobacco .	when was the first plastome sequenced ?	and first sequenced in 1986 -- when two japanese research teams sequenced the chloroplast dna of liverwort and tobacco

the inverted repeat regions are highly conserved among land plants , and accumulate few mutations .	what seldom mutates ?	the inverted repeat regions are highly conserved among land plants
similar inverted repeats exist in the genomes of cyanobacteria and the other two chloroplast lineages -lrb- glaucophyta and rhodophyceæ -rrb- , suggesting that they predate the chloroplast , though some chloroplast dnas have since lost or flipped the inverted repeats -lrb- making them direct repeats -rrb- .	what have some inverted repeats become ?	similar inverted repeats exist in the genomes of cyanobacteria and the other two chloroplast lineages -lrb- glaucophyta and rhodophyceæ -rrb-
it is possible that the inverted repeats help stabilize the rest of the chloroplast genome , as chloroplast dnas which have lost some of the inverted repeat segments tend to get rearranged more .	what could inverted repeats help do ?	as chloroplast dnas which have lost some of the inverted repeat segments tend to get rearranged more
scientists have attempted to observe chloroplast replication via electron microscopy since the 1970s .	how is chloroplast replication observed ?	scientists have attempted to observe chloroplast replication via electron microscopy since the 1970s
the mechanism for chloroplast dna -lrb- cpdna -rrb- replication has not been conclusively determined , but two main models have been proposed .	how many major chloroplast replication models have been suggested ?	the mechanism for chloroplast dna -lrb- cpdna -rrb- replication has not been conclusively determined
as the d-loop moves through the circular dna , it adopts a theta intermediary form , also known as a cairns replication intermediate , and completes replication with a rolling circle mechanism .	what is a cairns replication intermediate ?	and completes replication with a rolling circle mechanism
as the d-loop moves through the circular dna , it adopts a theta intermediary form , also known as a cairns replication intermediate , and completes replication with a rolling circle mechanism .	what is a d-loop ?	and completes replication with a rolling circle mechanism
as the d-loop moves through the circular dna , it adopts a theta intermediary form , also known as a cairns replication intermediate , and completes replication with a rolling circle mechanism .	how does the d-loop finish replicating ?	and completes replication with a rolling circle mechanism
in cpdna , there are several a → g deamination gradients .	what kind of gradients does cpdna have ?	there are several a → g deamination gradients
dna becomes susceptible to deamination events when it is single stranded .	what makes dna vulnerable to deamination ?	dna becomes susceptible to deamination events when it is single stranded
this mechanism is still the leading theory today ; however , a second theory suggests that most cpdna is actually linear and replicates through homologous recombination .	how does the secondary theory say most cpdna is structured ?	a second theory suggests that most cpdna is actually linear and replicates through homologous recombination
this mechanism is still the leading theory today ; however , a second theory suggests that most cpdna is actually linear and replicates through homologous recombination .	how does the secondary theory say most cpdna replicates ?	a second theory suggests that most cpdna is actually linear and replicates through homologous recombination
it further contends that only a minority of the genetic material is kept in circular chromosomes while the rest is in branched , linear , or other complex structures .	where does the secondary theory say most genes are kept ?	it further contends that only a minority of the genetic material is kept in circular chromosomes while the rest is in branched
one of competing model for cpdna replication asserts that most cpdna is linear and participates in homologous recombination and replication structures similar to bacteriophage t4 .	what is cpdna 's replication similar to ?	one of competing model for cpdna replication asserts that most cpdna is linear and participates in homologous recombination and replication structures similar to bacteriophage t4
it has been established that some plants have linear cpdna , such as maize , and that more species still contain complex structures that scientists do not yet understand .	what kind of cpdna does maize have ?	and that more species still contain complex structures that scientists do not yet understand
because of the failure to explain the deamination gradient as well as the numerous plant species that have been shown to have circular cpdna , the predominant theory continues to hold that most cpdna is circular and most likely replicates via a d loop mechanism .	how is most plants ' cpdna arranged ?	because of the failure to explain the deamination gradient as well as the numerous plant species that have been shown to have circular cpdna
because of the failure to explain the deamination gradient as well as the numerous plant species that have been shown to have circular cpdna , the predominant theory continues to hold that most cpdna is circular and most likely replicates via a d loop mechanism .	how does most plants ' cpdna replicate ?	because of the failure to explain the deamination gradient as well as the numerous plant species that have been shown to have circular cpdna
endosymbiotic gene transfer is how we know about the lost chloroplasts in many chromalveolate lineages .	what shows us lost chloroplasts ?	endosymbiotic gene transfer is how we know about the lost chloroplasts in many chromalveolate lineages
even if a chloroplast is eventually lost , the genes it donated to the former host 's nucleus persist , providing evidence for the lost chloroplast 's existence .	what do donated genes give evidence of ?	the genes it donated to the former host 's nucleus persist
for example , while diatoms -lrb- a heterokontophyte -rrb- now have a red algal derived chloroplast , the presence of many green algal genes in the diatom nucleus provide evidence that the diatom ancestor -lrb- probably the ancestor of all chromalveolates too -rrb- had a green algal derived chloroplast at some point , which was subsequently replaced by the red chloroplast .	what kind of chloroplasts do diatoms have ?	the presence of many green algal genes in the diatom nucleus provide evidence that the diatom ancestor -lrb- probably the ancestor of all chromalveolates too -rrb- had a green algal derived chloroplast at some point

the fact that chloroplasts are surrounded by a double membrane is often cited as evidence that they are the descendants of endosymbiotic cyanobacteria .	what is evidence chloroplasts descended from endosymbiotic cyanobacteria ?	the fact that chloroplasts are surrounded by a double membrane is often cited as evidence that they are the descendants of endosymbiotic cyanobacteria
this is often interpreted as meaning the outer chloroplast membrane is the product of the host 's cell membrane infolding to form a vesicle to surround the ancestral cyanobacterium -- which is not true -- both chloroplast membranes are homologous to the cyanobacterium 's original double membranes .	what is incorrectly thought about the outer chloroplast membrane ?	this is often interpreted as meaning the outer chloroplast membrane is the product of the host 's cell membrane infolding to form a vesicle to surround the ancestral cyanobacterium -- which is not true -- both chloroplast membranes are homologous to the cyanobacterium 's original double membranes

the chloroplast peripheral reticulum consists of a maze of membranous tubes and vesicles continuous with the inner chloroplast membrane that extends into the internal stromal fluid of the chloroplast .	what is a maze of membranous tubes ?	the chloroplast peripheral reticulum consists of a maze of membranous tubes and vesicles continuous with the inner chloroplast membrane that extends into the internal stromal fluid of the chloroplast

plastoglobuli were once thought to be free-floating in the stroma , but it is now thought that they are permanently attached either to a thylakoid or to another plastoglobulus attached to a thylakoid , a configuration that allows a plastoglobulus to exchange its contents with the thylakoid network .	what are plastoglobuli attached to ?	but it is now thought that they are permanently attached either to a thylakoid or to another plastoglobulus attached to a thylakoid

in old or stressed chloroplasts , plastoglobuli tend to occur in linked groups or chains , still always anchored to a thylakoid .	when do plastoglobuli occur in linked groups ?	plastoglobuli tend to occur in linked groups or chains

atp synthase is a large protein complex that harnesses the concentration gradient of the hydrogen ions in the thylakoid space to generate atp energy as the hydrogen ions flow back out into the stroma -- much like a dam turbine .	what is atp synthase similar to ?	atp synthase is a large protein complex that harnesses the concentration gradient of the hydrogen ions in the thylakoid space to generate atp energy as the hydrogen ions flow back out into the stroma -- much like a dam turbine

to fix carbon dioxide into sugar molecules in the process of photosynthesis , chloroplasts use an enzyme called rubisco .	what do chloroplasts use to fix carbon dioxide into sugar ?	to fix carbon dioxide into sugar molecules in the process of photosynthesis
rubisco has a problem -- it has trouble distinguishing between carbon dioxide and oxygen , so at high oxygen concentrations , rubisco starts accidentally adding oxygen to sugar precursors .	what is rubisco 's flaw ?	rubisco has a problem -- it has trouble distinguishing between carbon dioxide and oxygen
rubisco has a problem -- it has trouble distinguishing between carbon dioxide and oxygen , so at high oxygen concentrations , rubisco starts accidentally adding oxygen to sugar precursors .	what effect does rubisco 's flaw have ?	rubisco has a problem -- it has trouble distinguishing between carbon dioxide and oxygen
this is a big problem , since o2 is produced by the initial light reactions of photosynthesis , causing issues down the line in the calvin cycle which uses rubisco .	what process down the line does rubisco 's flaw interfere with ?	since o2 is produced by the initial light reactions of photosynthesis
this has the end result of atp energy being wasted and co2 being released , all with no sugar being produced .	what is wasted by rubisco 's flaw ?	this has the end result of atp energy being wasted and co2 being released
in mesophyll cells , chloroplasts are specialized for the light reactions , so they lack rubisco , and have normal grana and thylakoids , which they use to make atp and nadph , as well as oxygen .	what are chloroplasts in mesophyll cells specialized for ?	chloroplasts are specialized for the light reactions

they store co2 in a four-carbon compound , which is why the process is called c4 photosynthesis .	what do chloroplasts in mesophyll cells store carbon dioxide in ?	which is why the process is called c4 photosynthesis

a plant cell which contains chloroplasts is known as a chlorenchyma cell .	what is a chlorenchyma cell ?	a plant cell which contains chloroplasts is known as a chlorenchyma cell
in some plants such as cacti , chloroplasts are found in the stems , though in most plants , chloroplasts are concentrated in the leaves .	where do cacti have chloroplasts ?	chloroplasts are concentrated in the leaves
