palisade mesophyll cells can contain 30 -- 70 chloroplasts per cell , while stomatal guard cells contain only around 8 -- 15 per cell , as well as much less chlorophyll .	how many chloroplasts are in stomatal guard cells ?	palisade mesophyll cells can contain 30 -- 70 chloroplasts per cell
one square millimeter of leaf tissue can contain half a million chloroplasts .	how many chloroplasts are in a square mm of a leaf ?	one square millimeter of leaf tissue can contain half a million chloroplasts
within a leaf , chloroplasts are mainly found in the mesophyll layers of a leaf , and the guard cells of stomata .	what layers of a leaf have chloroplasts ?	chloroplasts are mainly found in the mesophyll layers of a leaf
in low-light conditions , they will spread out in a sheet -- maximizing the surface area to absorb light .	when do chloroplasts spread out flat ?	they will spread out in a sheet -- maximizing the surface area to absorb light
under intense light , they will seek shelter by aligning in vertical columns along the plant cell 's cell wall or turning sideways so that light strikes them edge-on .	when do chloroplasts arrange in vertical columns or turn sideways ?	they will seek shelter by aligning in vertical columns along the plant cell 's cell wall or turning sideways so that light strikes them edge-on
this reduces exposure and protects them from photooxidative damage .	what does turning sideways protect chloroplasts from ?	this reduces exposure and protects them from photooxidative damage
this ability to distribute chloroplasts so that they can take shelter behind each other or spread out may be the reason why land plants evolved to have many small chloroplasts instead of a few big ones .	why do land plants have more and smaller chloroplasts ?	this ability to distribute chloroplasts so that they can take shelter behind each other or spread out may be the reason why land plants evolved to have many small chloroplasts instead of a few big ones
mitochondria have also been observed to follow chloroplasts as they move .	what sometimes follows moving chloroplasts ?	mitochondria have also been observed to follow chloroplasts as they move
plants have two main immune responses -- the hypersensitive response , in which infected cells seal themselves off and undergo programmed cell death , and systemic acquired resistance , where infected cells release signals warning the rest of the plant of a pathogen 's presence .	how many major immune responses do plants have ?	where infected cells release signals warning the rest of the plant of a pathogen 's presence
plants have two main immune responses -- the hypersensitive response , in which infected cells seal themselves off and undergo programmed cell death , and systemic acquired resistance , where infected cells release signals warning the rest of the plant of a pathogen 's presence .	what is the hypersensitive response of a plant immune system ?	where infected cells release signals warning the rest of the plant of a pathogen 's presence
plants have two main immune responses -- the hypersensitive response , in which infected cells seal themselves off and undergo programmed cell death , and systemic acquired resistance , where infected cells release signals warning the rest of the plant of a pathogen 's presence .	what is the systemic acquired resistance response of a plant immune system ?	where infected cells release signals warning the rest of the plant of a pathogen 's presence
chloroplasts stimulate both responses by purposely damaging their photosynthetic system , producing reactive oxygen species .	how do chloroplasts trigger the plant 's immune system ?	chloroplasts stimulate both responses by purposely damaging their photosynthetic system
chloroplasts stimulate both responses by purposely damaging their photosynthetic system , producing reactive oxygen species .	what does damaging photosynthesis systems create ?	chloroplasts stimulate both responses by purposely damaging their photosynthetic system
after detecting stress in a cell , which might be due to a pathogen , chloroplasts begin producing molecules like salicylic acid , jasmonic acid , nitric oxide and reactive oxygen species which can serve as defense-signals .	what molecules act as defense signals ?	nitric oxide and reactive oxygen species which can serve as defense-signals
after detecting stress in a cell , which might be due to a pathogen , chloroplasts begin producing molecules like salicylic acid , jasmonic acid , nitric oxide and reactive oxygen species which can serve as defense-signals .	when do chloroplasts produce defense signals ?	nitric oxide and reactive oxygen species which can serve as defense-signals
as cellular signals , reactive oxygen species are unstable molecules , so they probably do n't leave the chloroplast , but instead pass on their signal to an unknown second messenger molecule .	what happens to reactive oxygen species signals since they do n't leave the chloroplast ?	but instead pass on their signal to an unknown second messenger molecule
all these molecules initiate retrograde signaling -- signals from the chloroplast that regulate gene expression in the nucleus .	what is retrograde signaling ?	all these molecules initiate retrograde signaling -- signals from the chloroplast that regulate gene expression in the nucleus
one of the main functions of the chloroplast is its role in photosynthesis , the process by which light is transformed into chemical energy , to subsequently produce food in the form of sugars .	what is the most important role of chloroplasts ?	one of the main functions of the chloroplast is its role in photosynthesis
one of the main functions of the chloroplast is its role in photosynthesis , the process by which light is transformed into chemical energy , to subsequently produce food in the form of sugars .	what is the process of changing light into chemical energy ?	one of the main functions of the chloroplast is its role in photosynthesis
one of the main functions of the chloroplast is its role in photosynthesis , the process by which light is transformed into chemical energy , to subsequently produce food in the form of sugars .	what is chemical energy used to produce in plants ?	one of the main functions of the chloroplast is its role in photosynthesis
water -lrb- h2o -rrb- and carbon dioxide -lrb- co2 -rrb- are used in photosynthesis , and sugar and oxygen -lrb- o2 -rrb- is made , using light energy .	what are the molecular inputs for photosynthesis ?	water -lrb- h2o -rrb- and carbon dioxide -lrb- co2 -rrb- are used in photosynthesis
water -lrb- h2o -rrb- and carbon dioxide -lrb- co2 -rrb- are used in photosynthesis , and sugar and oxygen -lrb- o2 -rrb- is made , using light energy .	what are the molecular outputs for photosynthesis ?	water -lrb- h2o -rrb- and carbon dioxide -lrb- co2 -rrb- are used in photosynthesis
like mitochondria , chloroplasts use the potential energy stored in an h + , or hydrogen ion gradient to generate atp energy .	what do chloroplasts do like mitochondria ?	chloroplasts use the potential energy stored in an h +
the molecules between the photosystems harness the electrons ' energy to pump hydrogen ions into the thylakoid space , creating a concentration gradient , with more hydrogen ions -lrb- up to a thousand times as many -rrb- inside the thylakoid system than in the stroma .	where do chloroplasts pump hydrogen ?	the molecules between the photosystems harness the electrons ' energy to pump hydrogen ions into the thylakoid space
the molecules between the photosystems harness the electrons ' energy to pump hydrogen ions into the thylakoid space , creating a concentration gradient , with more hydrogen ions -lrb- up to a thousand times as many -rrb- inside the thylakoid system than in the stroma .	how concentrated do the hydrogen ions get in the thylakoid space ?	the molecules between the photosystems harness the electrons ' energy to pump hydrogen ions into the thylakoid space
atp synthase uses the energy from the flowing hydrogen ions to phosphorylate adenosine diphosphate into adenosine triphosphate , or atp .	what does atp synthase change into atp ?	atp synthase uses the energy from the flowing hydrogen ions to phosphorylate adenosine diphosphate into adenosine triphosphate
atp synthase uses the energy from the flowing hydrogen ions to phosphorylate adenosine diphosphate into adenosine triphosphate , or atp .	what does atp mean ?	atp synthase uses the energy from the flowing hydrogen ions to phosphorylate adenosine diphosphate into adenosine triphosphate
normally , the reenergized electrons are taken by nadp + , though sometimes they can flow back down more h + - pumping electron transport chains to transport more hydrogen ions into the thylakoid space to generate more atp .	what usually takes reenergized electrons ?	though sometimes they can flow back down more h + - pumping electron transport chains to transport more hydrogen ions into the thylakoid space to generate more atp
this is termed cyclic photophosphorylation because the electrons are recycled .	in what process are electrons recycled ?	this is termed cyclic photophosphorylation because the electrons are recycled
cyclic photophosphorylation is common in c4 plants , which need more atp than nadph .	where is cyclic photophosphorylation common ?	cyclic photophosphorylation is common in c4 plants
cyclic photophosphorylation is common in c4 plants , which need more atp than nadph .	what do c4 plants need ?	cyclic photophosphorylation is common in c4 plants
the calvin cycle starts by using the enzyme rubisco to fix co2 into five-carbon ribulose bisphosphate -lrb- rubp -rrb- molecules .	what cycle starts with rubisco ?	the calvin cycle starts by using the enzyme rubisco to fix co2 into five-carbon ribulose bisphosphate -lrb- rubp -rrb- molecules
the result is unstable six-carbon molecules that immediately break down into three-carbon molecules called 3-phosphoglyceric acid , or 3-pga .	what is the result of the calvin cycle ?	the result is unstable six-carbon molecules that immediately break down into three-carbon molecules called 3-phosphoglyceric acid
the result is unstable six-carbon molecules that immediately break down into three-carbon molecules called 3-phosphoglyceric acid , or 3-pga .	what do unstable 6-carbon molecules become ?	the result is unstable six-carbon molecules that immediately break down into three-carbon molecules called 3-phosphoglyceric acid
most of the g3p molecules are recycled back into rubp using energy from more atp , but one out of every six produced leaves the cycle -- the end product of the dark reactions .	how many g3p molecules leave the cycle ?	but one out of every six produced leaves the cycle -- the end product of the dark reactions
alternatively , glucose monomers in the chloroplast can be linked together to make starch , which accumulates into the starch grains found in the chloroplast .	what is an alternate way to make starch ?	glucose monomers in the chloroplast can be linked together to make starch
under conditions such as high atmospheric co2 concentrations , these starch grains may grow very large , distorting the grana and thylakoids .	when might starch grains become overly large ?	under conditions such as high atmospheric co2 concentrations

while linked to low photosynthesis rates , the starch grains themselves may not necessarily interfere significantly with the efficiency of photosynthesis , and might simply be a side effect of another photosynthesis-depressing factor .	what might starch grains be a side effect of ?	the starch grains themselves may not necessarily interfere significantly with the efficiency of photosynthesis
rubisco can not distinguish between oxygen and carbon dioxide very well , so it can accidentally add o2 instead of co2 to rubp .	what can rubisco do by mistake ?	rubisco can not distinguish between oxygen and carbon dioxide very well
photorespiration can occur when the oxygen concentration is too high .	when does photorespiration happen ?	photorespiration can occur when the oxygen concentration is too high

chloroplasts are a special type of a plant cell organelle called a plastid , though the two terms are sometimes used interchangeably .	what is sometimes used interchangeably with ` plastids ' ?	chloroplasts are a special type of a plant cell organelle called a plastid
all chloroplasts in a plant are descended from undifferentiated proplastids found in the zygote , or fertilized egg .	what do a plant 's chloroplasts descend from ?	all chloroplasts in a plant are descended from undifferentiated proplastids found in the zygote
proplastids are commonly found in an adult plant 's apical meristems .	where are proplastids usually found ?	proplastids are commonly found in an adult plant 's apical meristems
chloroplasts do not normally develop from proplastids in root tip meristems -- instead , the formation of starch-storing amyloplasts is more common .	what is more often seen in root tip maristems ?	chloroplasts do not normally develop from proplastids in root tip meristems -- instead
if angiosperm shoots are not exposed to the required light for chloroplast formation , proplastids may develop into an etioplast stage before becoming chloroplasts .	what happens if angiosperm shoots do n't get enough light ?	if angiosperm shoots are not exposed to the required light for chloroplast formation
an etioplast is a plastid that lacks chlorophyll , and has inner membrane invaginations that form a lattice of tubes in their stroma , called a prolamellar body .	what is an etioplast ?	and has inner membrane invaginations that form a lattice of tubes in their stroma
an etioplast is a plastid that lacks chlorophyll , and has inner membrane invaginations that form a lattice of tubes in their stroma , called a prolamellar body .	what do etioplasts ' internal membranes have ?	and has inner membrane invaginations that form a lattice of tubes in their stroma
while etioplasts lack chlorophyll , they have a yellow chlorophyll precursor stocked .	what do etioplasts have instead of chlorophyll ?	they have a yellow chlorophyll precursor stocked
gymnosperms do not require light to form chloroplasts .	what plants do n't need light to make chloroplasts ?	gymnosperms do not require light to form chloroplasts

a prime number -lrb- or a prime -rrb- is a natural number greater than 1 that has no positive divisors other than 1 and itself .	what is the only divisor besides 1 that a prime number can have ?	a prime number -lrb- or a prime -rrb- is a natural number greater than 1 that has no positive divisors other than 1 and itself
a natural number greater than 1 that is not a prime number is called a composite number .	what are numbers greater than 1 that can be divided by 3 or more numbers called ?	a natural number greater than 1 that is not a prime number is called a composite number
the fundamental theorem of arithmetic establishes the central role of primes in number theory : any integer greater than 1 can be expressed as a product of primes that is unique up to ordering .	what theorem defines the main role of primes in number theory ?	the fundamental theorem of arithmetic establishes the central role of primes in number theory : any integer greater than 1 can be expressed as a product of primes that is unique up to ordering
the fundamental theorem of arithmetic establishes the central role of primes in number theory : any integer greater than 1 can be expressed as a product of primes that is unique up to ordering .	any number larger than 1 can be represented as a product of what ?	the fundamental theorem of arithmetic establishes the central role of primes in number theory : any integer greater than 1 can be expressed as a product of primes that is unique up to ordering
the uniqueness in this theorem requires excluding 1 as a prime because one can include arbitrarily many instances of 1 in any factorization , e.g. , 3 , 1 · 3 , 1 · 1 · 3 , etc. are all valid factorizations of 3 .	why must one be excluded in order to preserve the uniqueness of the fundamental theorem ?	the uniqueness in this theorem requires excluding 1 as a prime because one can include arbitrarily many instances of 1 in any factorization
the property of being prime -lrb- or not -rrb- is called primality .	what is the name of the property that designates a number as being prime or not ?	the property of being prime -lrb- or not -rrb- is called primality
a simple but slow method of verifying the primality of a given number n is known as trial division .	what is the name of the process which confirms the primality of a number n ?	a simple but slow method of verifying the primality of a given number n is known as trial division
these include the miller -- rabin primality test , which is fast but has a small probability of error , and the aks primality test , which always produces the correct answer in polynomial time but is too slow to be practical .	what is the name of one algorithm useful for conveniently testing the primality of large numbers ?	which always produces the correct answer in polynomial time but is too slow to be practical
these include the miller -- rabin primality test , which is fast but has a small probability of error , and the aks primality test , which always produces the correct answer in polynomial time but is too slow to be practical .	what is the name of another algorithm useful for conveniently testing the primality of large numbers ?	which always produces the correct answer in polynomial time but is too slow to be practical

the first result in that direction is the prime number theorem , proven at the end of the 19th century , which says that the probability that a given , randomly chosen number n is prime is inversely proportional to its number of digits , or to the logarithm of n.	what theorem states that the probability that a number n is prime is inversely proportional to its logarithm ?	randomly chosen number n is prime is inversely proportional to its number of digits

many questions regarding prime numbers remain open , such as goldbach 's conjecture -lrb- that every even integer greater than 2 can be expressed as the sum of two primes -rrb- , and the twin prime conjecture -lrb- that there are infinitely many pairs of primes whose difference is 2 -rrb- .	what is the name of the supposition that any number larger than 2 can be represented as the sum of two primes ?	such as goldbach 's conjecture -lrb- that every even integer greater than 2 can be expressed as the sum of two primes -rrb-

modern primality tests for general numbers n can be divided into two main classes , probabilistic -lrb- or `` monte carlo '' -rrb- and deterministic algorithms .	what is the name of another type of modern primality test ?	modern primality tests for general numbers n can be divided into two main classes
for example , trial division is a deterministic algorithm because , if performed correctly , it will always identify a prime number as prime and a composite number as composite .	what type of algorithm is trial division ?	it will always identify a prime number as prime and a composite number as composite
if we repeat the test n times and pass every time , then the probability that our number is composite is 1 / -lrb- 1-p -rrb- n , which decreases exponentially with the number of tests , so we can be as sure as we like -lrb- though never perfectly sure -rrb- that the number is prime .	when using a probabilistic algorithm , how is the probability that the number is composite expressed mathematically ?	so we can be as sure as we like -lrb- though never perfectly sure -rrb- that the number is prime
a particularly simple example of a probabilistic test is the fermat primality test , which relies on the fact -lrb- fermat 's little theorem -rrb- that np ≡ n -lrb- mod p -rrb- for any n if p is a prime number .	what is one straightforward case of a probabilistic test ?	which relies on the fact -lrb- fermat 's little theorem -rrb- that np ≡ n -lrb- mod p -rrb- for any n if p is a prime number
a particularly simple example of a probabilistic test is the fermat primality test , which relies on the fact -lrb- fermat 's little theorem -rrb- that np ≡ n -lrb- mod p -rrb- for any n if p is a prime number .	what does the fermat primality test depend upon ?	which relies on the fact -lrb- fermat 's little theorem -rrb- that np ≡ n -lrb- mod p -rrb- for any n if p is a prime number
a flaw with this test is that there are some composite numbers -lrb- the carmichael numbers -rrb- that satisfy the fermat identity even though they are not prime , so the test has no way of distinguishing between prime numbers and carmichael numbers .	what type of numbers demonstrate a flaw with the fermat primality test ?	a flaw with this test is that there are some composite numbers -lrb- the carmichael numbers -rrb- that satisfy the fermat identity even though they are not prime
more powerful extensions of the fermat primality test , such as the baillie-psw , miller-rabin , and solovay-strassen tests , are guaranteed to fail at least some of the time when applied to a composite number .	what is the name of one impressive continuation of the fermat primality test ?	are guaranteed to fail at least some of the time when applied to a composite number

these conjectures are special cases of the broad schinzel 's hypothesis h. brocard 's conjecture says that there are always at least four primes between the squares of consecutive primes greater than 2 .	what conjecture holds that there are always a minimum of 4 primes between the squares of consecutive primes greater than 2 ?	brocard 's conjecture says that there are always at least four primes between the squares of consecutive primes greater than 2
for a long time , number theory in general , and the study of prime numbers in particular , was seen as the canonical example of pure mathematics , with no applications outside of the self-interest of studying the topic with the exception of use of prime numbered gear teeth to distribute wear evenly .	besides the study of prime numbers , what general theory was considered the official example of pure mathematics ?	with no applications outside of the self-interest of studying the topic with the exception of use of prime numbered gear teeth to distribute wear evenly
in particular , number theorists such as british mathematician g. h. hardy prided themselves on doing work that had absolutely no military significance .	what british mathematician took pride in doing work that he felt had no military benefit ?	hardy prided themselves on doing work that had absolutely no military significance
however , this vision was shattered in the 1970s , when it was publicly announced that prime numbers could be used as the basis for the creation of public key cryptography algorithms .	when was it discovered that prime numbers could applied to the creation of public key cryptography algorithms ?	when it was publicly announced that prime numbers could be used as the basis for the creation of public key cryptography algorithms
prime numbers are also used for hash tables and pseudorandom number generators .	besides public key cryptography , what is another application for prime numbers ?	prime numbers are also used for hash tables and pseudorandom number generators
prime numbers are also used for hash tables and pseudorandom number generators .	what type of number generators make use of prime numbers ?	prime numbers are also used for hash tables and pseudorandom number generators

these insects spend most of their lives as grubs underground .	where do cicadas spend the majority of their lives ?	these insects spend most of their lives as grubs underground
they only pupate and then emerge from their burrows after 7 , 13 or 17 years , at which point they fly about , breed , and then die after a few weeks at most .	other than 7 and 13 , what other year interval do cicadas pupate ?	they only pupate and then emerge from their burrows after 7
the logic for this is believed to be that the prime number intervals between emergences make it very difficult for predators to evolve that could specialize as predators on magicicadas .	what is the logic behind the cicadas prime number evolutionary strategy ?	the logic for this is believed to be that the prime number intervals between emergences make it very difficult for predators to evolve that could specialize as predators on magicicadas

generally , `` prime '' indicates minimality or indecomposability , in an appropriate sense .	what does the word prime generally suggest ?	`` prime '' indicates minimality or indecomposability
for example , the prime field is the smallest subfield of a field f containing both 0 and 1 .	for a field f containing 0 and 1 , what would be the prime field ?	the prime field is the smallest subfield of a field f containing both 0 and 1
any knot can be uniquely expressed as a connected sum of prime knots .	how can any knot be distinctively indicated ?	any knot can be uniquely expressed as a connected sum of prime knots
often a second , additional meaning is intended by using the word prime , namely that any object can be , essentially uniquely , decomposed into its prime components .	what is an additional meaning intended when the word prime is used ?	additional meaning is intended by using the word prime
for example , in knot theory , a prime knot is a knot that is indecomposable in the sense that it can not be written as the knot sum of two nontrivial knots .	what does it mean for a knot to be considered indecomposable ?	a prime knot is a knot that is indecomposable in the sense that it can not be written as the knot sum of two nontrivial knots

prime numbers give rise to two more general concepts that apply to elements of any commutative ring r , an algebraic structure where addition , subtraction and multiplication are defined : prime elements and irreducible elements .	what is another general concept that applies to elements of commutative rings ?	prime numbers give rise to two more general concepts that apply to elements of any commutative ring r
an element p of r is called prime element if it is neither zero nor a unit -lrb- i.e. , does not have a multiplicative inverse -rrb- and satisfies the following requirement : given x and y in r such that p divides the product xy , then p divides x or y .	what is one condition that an element p of r must satisfy in order to be considered a prime element ?	does not have a multiplicative inverse -rrb- and satisfies the following requirement : given x and y in r such that p divides the product xy
an element is irreducible if it is not a unit and can not be written as a product of two ring elements that are not units .	under what condition is an element irreducible ?	an element is irreducible if it is not a unit and can not be written as a product of two ring elements that are not units

in ring theory , the notion of number is generally replaced with that of ideal .	in what theory is the idea of a number exchanged with that of an ideal ?	the notion of number is generally replaced with that of ideal
prime ideals , which generalize prime elements in the sense that the principal ideal generated by a prime element is a prime ideal , are an important tool and object of study in commutative algebra , algebraic number theory and algebraic geometry .	what type of ideals generalize prime elements ?	which generalize prime elements in the sense that the principal ideal generated by a prime element is a prime ideal
prime ideals , which generalize prime elements in the sense that the principal ideal generated by a prime element is a prime ideal , are an important tool and object of study in commutative algebra , algebraic number theory and algebraic geometry .	what type of number theory utilizes and studies prime ideals ?	which generalize prime elements in the sense that the principal ideal generated by a prime element is a prime ideal
the prime ideals of the ring of integers are the ideals -lrb- 0 -rrb- , -lrb- 2 -rrb- , -lrb- 3 -rrb- , -lrb- 5 -rrb- , -lrb- 7 -rrb- , -lrb- 11 -rrb- , ... the fundamental theorem of arithmetic generalizes to the lasker -- noether theorem , which expresses every ideal in a noetherian commutative ring as an intersection of primary ideals , which are the appropriate generalizations of prime powers .	which theorem can be simplified to the lasker -- noether theorem ?	which expresses every ideal in a noetherian commutative ring as an intersection of primary ideals
the prime ideals of the ring of integers are the ideals -lrb- 0 -rrb- , -lrb- 2 -rrb- , -lrb- 3 -rrb- , -lrb- 5 -rrb- , -lrb- 7 -rrb- , -lrb- 11 -rrb- , ... the fundamental theorem of arithmetic generalizes to the lasker -- noether theorem , which expresses every ideal in a noetherian commutative ring as an intersection of primary ideals , which are the appropriate generalizations of prime powers .	what type of commutative ring does the lasker -- noether theorem express every ideal as an intersection of primary ideals in ?	which expresses every ideal in a noetherian commutative ring as an intersection of primary ideals
prime ideals are the points of algebro-geometric objects , via the notion of the spectrum of a ring .	what are the points of algebro-geometric objects ?	prime ideals are the points of algebro-geometric objects
for example , factorization or ramification of prime ideals when lifted to an extension field , a basic problem of algebraic number theory , bears some resemblance with ramification in geometry .	what does factorization of prime ideals approximate ?	factorization or ramification of prime ideals when lifted to an extension field

in particular , this norm gets smaller when a number is multiplied by p , in sharp contrast to the usual absolute value -lrb- also referred to as the infinite prime -rrb- .	what happens to the norm when a number is multiplied by p ?	in sharp contrast to the usual absolute value -lrb- also referred to as the infinite prime -rrb-

while completing q -lrb- roughly , filling the gaps -rrb- with respect to the absolute value yields the field of real numbers , completing with respect to the p-adic norm | − | p yields the field of p-adic numbers .	completing q with respect to what will produce the field of real numbers ?	filling the gaps -rrb- with respect to the absolute value yields the field of real numbers
this local-global principle again underlines the importance of primes to number theory .	what principle highlights the significance of primes in number theory	this local-global principle again underlines the importance of primes to number theory
the french composer olivier messiaen used prime numbers to create ametrical music through `` natural phenomena '' .	which french composer wrote ametrical music using prime numbers ?	the french composer olivier messiaen used prime numbers to create ametrical music through `` natural phenomena ''
in works such as la nativité du seigneur -lrb- 1935 -rrb- and quatre études de rythme -lrb- 1949 -- 50 -rrb- , he simultaneously employs motifs with lengths given by different prime numbers to create unpredictable rhythms : the primes 41 , 43 , 47 and 53 appear in the third étude , `` neumes rythmiques '' .	what is one work by olivier messiaen ?	he simultaneously employs motifs with lengths given by different prime numbers to create unpredictable rhythms : the primes 41

the rhine -lrb- romansh : rein , german : rhein , french : le rhin , dutch : rijn -rrb- is a european river that begins in the swiss canton of graubünden in the southeastern swiss alps , forms part of the swiss-austrian , swiss-liechtenstein border , swiss-german and then the franco-german border , then flows through the rhineland and eventually empties into the north sea in the netherlands .	where does the rhine begin ?	dutch : rijn -rrb- is a european river that begins in the swiss canton of graubünden in the southeastern swiss alps
the rhine -lrb- romansh : rein , german : rhein , french : le rhin , dutch : rijn -rrb- is a european river that begins in the swiss canton of graubünden in the southeastern swiss alps , forms part of the swiss-austrian , swiss-liechtenstein border , swiss-german and then the franco-german border , then flows through the rhineland and eventually empties into the north sea in the netherlands .	where does the rhine empty ?	dutch : rijn -rrb- is a european river that begins in the swiss canton of graubünden in the southeastern swiss alps
the biggest city on the river rhine is cologne , germany with a population of more than 1,050,000 people .	what is the largest city the rhine runs through ?	the biggest city on the river rhine is cologne
it is the second-longest river in central and western europe -lrb- after the danube -rrb- , at about 1,230 km -lrb- 760 mi -rrb- , -lsb- note 2 -rsb- -lsb- note 1 -rsb- with an average discharge of about 2,900 m3/s -lrb- 100,000 cu ft/s -rrb- .	what river is larger than the rhine ?	it is the second-longest river in central and western europe -lrb- after the danube -rrb-

the variant forms of the name of the rhine in modern languages are all derived from the gaulish name rēnos , which was adapted in roman-era geography -lrb- 1st century bc -rrb- as greek ῥῆνος -lrb- rhēnos -rrb- , latin rhenus .	where does the name rhine derive from ?	the variant forms of the name of the rhine in modern languages are all derived from the gaulish name rēnos
-lsb- note 3 -rsb- the spelling with rh - in english rhine as well as in german rhein and french rhin is due to the influence of greek orthography , while the vocalisation - i - is due to the proto-germanic adoption of the gaulish name as * rīnaz , via old frankish giving old english rín , old high german rīn , dutch rijn -lrb- formerly also spelled rhijn -rrb- -rrb- .	what is the french name for the rhine ?	-lsb- note 3 -rsb- the spelling with rh - in english rhine as well as in german rhein and french rhin is due to the influence of greek orthography

the rhine emerges from lake constance , flows generally westward , as the hochrhein , passes the rhine falls , and is joined by its major tributary , the river aare .	what is the major tributary of the rhine ?	the rhine emerges from lake constance
the aare more than doubles the rhine 's water discharge , to an average of nearly 1,000 m3/s -lrb- 35,000 cu ft/s -rrb- , and provides more than a fifth of the discharge at the dutch border .	how much water does the aare give to the rhine ?	and provides more than a fifth of the discharge at the dutch border
the aare also contains the waters from the 4,274 m -lrb- 14,022 ft -rrb- summit of finsteraarhorn , the highest point of the rhine basin .	where is the highest point of the rhine basin ?	the aare also contains the waters from the 4
the rhine roughly forms the german-swiss border from lake constance with the exceptions of the canton of schaffhausen and parts of the cantons of zürich and basel-stadt , until it turns north at the so-called rhine knee at basel , leaving switzerland .	where is the so-called rhine knee ?	the rhine roughly forms the german-swiss border from lake constance with the exceptions of the canton of schaffhausen and parts of the cantons of zürich and basel-stadt

the ruhr , which joins the rhine in duisburg , is nowadays a clean river , thanks to a combination of stricter environmental controls , a transition from heavy industry to light industry and cleanup measures , such as the reforestation of slag and brownfields .	what rive joins the rhine in duisburg ?	a transition from heavy industry to light industry and cleanup measures

the name rijn , from here on , is used only for smaller streams farther to the north , which together formed the main river rhine in roman times .	what is the name for the smaller streams along the region northern germany ?	which together formed the main river rhine in roman times
though they retained the name , these streams no longer carry water from the rhine , but are used for draining the surrounding land and polders .	the smaller streams are used for what ?	but are used for draining the surrounding land and polders

the rhine-meuse delta , the most important natural region of the netherlands begins near millingen aan de rijn , close to the dutch-german border with the division of the rhine into waal and nederrijn .	what is the name of the delta in the netherlands ?	close to the dutch-german border with the division of the rhine into waal and nederrijn
the rhine-meuse delta , the most important natural region of the netherlands begins near millingen aan de rijn , close to the dutch-german border with the division of the rhine into waal and nederrijn .	where does the delta in the netherlands begin ?	close to the dutch-german border with the division of the rhine into waal and nederrijn
since the rhine contributes most of the water , the shorter term rhine delta is commonly used .	what is the nickname for the delta in the netherlands ?	since the rhine contributes most of the water
the shape of the rhine delta is determined by two bifurcations : first , at millingen aan de rijn , the rhine splits into waal and pannerdens kanaal , which changes its name to nederrijn at angeren , and second near arnhem , the ijssel branches off from the nederrijn .	at millingen aan de rijn where the rhine splits , what does it change it 's name to ?	the shape of the rhine delta is determined by two bifurcations : first
this creates three main flows , two of which change names rather often .	how many main flows are branched off from the nederrijn ?	two of which change names rather often
the largest and southern main branch begins as waal and continues as boven merwede -lrb- `` upper merwede '' -rrb- , beneden merwede -lrb- `` lower merwede '' -rrb- , noord river -lrb- `` north river '' -rrb- , nieuwe maas -lrb- `` new meuse '' -rrb- , het scheur -lrb- `` the rip '' -rrb- and nieuwe waterweg -lrb- `` new waterway '' -rrb- .	what is the largest main branch of the rhine ?	the largest and southern main branch begins as waal and continues as boven merwede -lrb- `` upper merwede '' -rrb-
three more flows carry significant amounts of water : the nieuwe merwede -lrb- `` new merwede '' -rrb- , which branches off from the southern branch where it changes from boven to beneden merwede ; the oude maas -lrb- `` old meuse '' -rrb- , which branches off from the southern branch where it changes from beneden merwede into noord , and dordtse kil , which branches off from oude maas .	what is the translation of oude maas ?	three more flows carry significant amounts of water : the nieuwe merwede -lrb- `` new merwede '' -rrb-
the largest and southern main branch begins as waal and continues as boven merwede -lrb- `` upper merwede '' -rrb- , beneden merwede -lrb- `` lower merwede '' -rrb- , noord river -lrb- `` north river '' -rrb- , nieuwe maas -lrb- `` new meuse '' -rrb- , het scheur -lrb- `` the rip '' -rrb- and nieuwe waterweg -lrb- `` new waterway '' -rrb- .	what is the english translation of het scheur ?	the largest and southern main branch begins as waal and continues as boven merwede -lrb- `` upper merwede '' -rrb-

at about 180 mbp , in the jurassic period , the two plates reversed direction and began to compress the tethys floor , causing it to be subducted under eurasia and pushing up the edge of the latter plate in the alpine orogeny of the oligocene and miocene periods .	what period did plates reverse directions to compress the tethys floor ?	causing it to be subducted under eurasia and pushing up the edge of the latter plate in the alpine orogeny of the oligocene and miocene periods

in southern europe , the stage was set in the triassic period of the mesozoic era , with the opening of the tethys ocean , between the eurasian and african tectonic plates , between about 240 mbp and 220 mbp -lrb- million years before present -rrb- .	what period opened the tethys ocean ?	between about 240 mbp and 220 mbp -lrb- million years before present -rrb-

from the eocene onwards , the ongoing alpine orogeny caused a n -- s rift system to develop in this zone .	what rift system developed in the alpine orogeny ?	the ongoing alpine orogeny caused a n -- s rift system to develop in this zone
the main elements of this rift are the upper rhine graben , in southwest germany and eastern france and the lower rhine embayment , in northwest germany and the southeastern netherlands .	what elements from the rift system in the alpine orogeny in southwest germany ?	in southwest germany and eastern france and the lower rhine embayment

seven days to the river rhine was a warsaw pact war plan for an invasion of western europe during the cold war .	what was the warsaw pact war plan ?	seven days to the river rhine was a warsaw pact war plan for an invasion of western europe during the cold war
until 1932 the generally accepted length of the rhine was 1,230 kilometres -lrb- 764 miles -rrb- .	what was the accepted length of the rhine prior to 1932 ?	until 1932 the generally accepted length of the rhine was 1
in 1932 the german encyclopedia knaurs lexikon stated the length as 1,320 kilometres -lrb- 820 miles -rrb- , presumably a typographical error .	who stated a change of the length of the rhine ?	in 1932 the german encyclopedia knaurs lexikon stated the length as 1
in 1932 the german encyclopedia knaurs lexikon stated the length as 1,320 kilometres -lrb- 820 miles -rrb- , presumably a typographical error .	why was the rhine measurement changed ?	in 1932 the german encyclopedia knaurs lexikon stated the length as 1
in 1932 the german encyclopedia knaurs lexikon stated the length as 1,320 kilometres -lrb- 820 miles -rrb- , presumably a typographical error .	in 1932 what was the rhine measurement changed to ?	in 1932 the german encyclopedia knaurs lexikon stated the length as 1
the error was discovered in 2010 , and the dutch rijkswaterstaat confirms the length at 1,232 kilometres -lrb- 766 miles -rrb- .	when was the rhine measurement corrected back to the original ?	and the dutch rijkswaterstaat confirms the length at 1
following a referendum in 1997 , in which the scottish electorate voted for devolution , the current parliament was convened by the scotland act 1998 , which sets out its powers as a devolved legislature .	when was the current parliament of scotland convened ?	the current parliament was convened by the scotland act 1998
following a referendum in 1997 , in which the scottish electorate voted for devolution , the current parliament was convened by the scotland act 1998 , which sets out its powers as a devolved legislature .	what act set out the parliament 's powers as a devolved legislature ?	the current parliament was convened by the scotland act 1998
the act delineates the legislative competence of the parliament -- the areas in which it can make laws -- by explicitly specifying powers that are `` reserved '' to the parliament of the united kingdom .	the legislative competence of the parliament species what areas ?	the act delineates the legislative competence of the parliament -- the areas in which it can make laws -- by explicitly specifying powers that are `` reserved '' to the parliament of the united kingdom
the act delineates the legislative competence of the parliament -- the areas in which it can make laws -- by explicitly specifying powers that are `` reserved '' to the parliament of the united kingdom .	to what body are certain powers explicitly specified as being reserved for ?	the act delineates the legislative competence of the parliament -- the areas in which it can make laws -- by explicitly specifying powers that are `` reserved '' to the parliament of the united kingdom
the scottish parliament has the power to legislate in all areas that are not explicitly reserved to westminster .	the scottish parliament may legislate as it pleases as long as the powers are n't already reserved by where ?	the scottish parliament has the power to legislate in all areas that are not explicitly reserved to westminster
for the next three hundred years , scotland was directly governed by the parliament of great britain and the subsequent parliament of the united kingdom , both seated at westminster , and the lack of a parliament of scotland remained an important element in scottish national identity .	what remained an important issue in scottish national identity for many years ?	scotland was directly governed by the parliament of great britain and the subsequent parliament of the united kingdom
for the next three hundred years , scotland was directly governed by the parliament of great britain and the subsequent parliament of the united kingdom , both seated at westminster , and the lack of a parliament of scotland remained an important element in scottish national identity .	how many hundred of years was scotland directly governed by the parliament of great britain ?	scotland was directly governed by the parliament of great britain and the subsequent parliament of the united kingdom
suggestions for a ` devolved ' parliament were made before 1914 , but were shelved due to the outbreak of the first world war .	why were the initial suggestions for a devolved parliament before 1914 shelved ?	suggestions for a ` devolved ' parliament were made before 1914
a sharp rise in nationalism in scotland during the late 1960s fuelled demands for some form of home rule or complete independence , and in 1969 prompted the incumbent labour government of harold wilson to set up the kilbrandon commission to consider the british constitution .	when was there a sharp rise in nationalism in scotland ?	and in 1969 prompted the incumbent labour government of harold wilson to set up the kilbrandon commission to consider the british constitution
kilbrandon published his report in 1973 recommending the establishment of a directly elected scottish assembly to legislate for the majority of domestic scottish affairs .	what did kllbrandon 's report in 1973 recommend establishing ?	kilbrandon published his report in 1973 recommending the establishment of a directly elected scottish assembly to legislate for the majority of domestic scottish affairs
during this time , the discovery of oil in the north sea and the following `` it 's scotland 's oil '' campaign of the scottish national party -lrb- snp -rrb- resulted in rising support for scottish independence , as well as the snp .	which sea was oil discovered in ?	the discovery of oil in the north sea and the following `` it 's scotland 's oil '' campaign of the scottish national party -lrb- snp -rrb- resulted in rising support for scottish independence
during this time , the discovery of oil in the north sea and the following `` it 's scotland 's oil '' campaign of the scottish national party -lrb- snp -rrb- resulted in rising support for scottish independence , as well as the snp .	what campaigh did the scottish national party -lrb- snp -rrb- run ?	the discovery of oil in the north sea and the following `` it 's scotland 's oil '' campaign of the scottish national party -lrb- snp -rrb- resulted in rising support for scottish independence
the combined effect of these events led to prime minister wilson committing his government to some form of devolved legislature in 1974 .	when did prime minister wilson commit to some form of devolved legislature ?	the combined effect of these events led to prime minister wilson committing his government to some form of devolved legislature in 1974
the party argued that the revenues from the oil were not benefitting scotland as much as they should .	what did the snp publicly opine about the oil revenues ?	the party argued that the revenues from the oil were not benefitting scotland as much as they should
however , it was not until 1978 that final legislative proposals for a scottish assembly were passed by the united kingdom parliament .	when was the final legislative proposals for a scottish assembly passed ?	it was not until 1978 that final legislative proposals for a scottish assembly were passed by the united kingdom parliament
under the terms of the scotland act 1978 , an elected assembly would be set up in edinburgh provided that the majority of the scottish electorate voted for it in a referendum to be held on 1 march 1979 that represented at least 40 % of the total electorate .	where was an elected assembly to be set up , under the terms of the scotland act of 1978 ?	an elected assembly would be set up in edinburgh provided that the majority of the scottish electorate voted for it in a referendum to be held on 1 march 1979 that represented at least 40 % of the total electorate
under the terms of the scotland act 1978 , an elected assembly would be set up in edinburgh provided that the majority of the scottish electorate voted for it in a referendum to be held on 1 march 1979 that represented at least 40 % of the total electorate .	how many of the scottish electorate would need to for it on the referendum ?	an elected assembly would be set up in edinburgh provided that the majority of the scottish electorate voted for it in a referendum to be held on 1 march 1979 that represented at least 40 % of the total electorate
although the vote was 51.6 % in favour of a scottish assembly , this figure did not equal the 40 % of the total electorate threshold deemed necessary to pass the measure , as 32.9 % of the eligible voting population did not , or had been unable to , vote .	what percentage of the vote for a scottish assembly in favor of it ?	this figure did not equal the 40 % of the total electorate threshold deemed necessary to pass the measure
the 1979 scottish devolution referendum to establish a devolved scottish assembly failed .	how did trying to establish a devolved scottish assembly go in 1979 ?	the 1979 scottish devolution referendum to establish a devolved scottish assembly failed
although the vote was 51.6 % in favour of a scottish assembly , this figure did not equal the 40 % of the total electorate threshold deemed necessary to pass the measure , as 32.9 % of the eligible voting population did not , or had been unable to , vote .	what percentage of scotland 's voting population failed to actually vote ?	this figure did not equal the 40 % of the total electorate threshold deemed necessary to pass the measure
throughout the 1980s and 1990s , demand for a scottish parliament grew , in part because the government of the united kingdom was controlled by the conservative party , while scotland itself elected relatively few conservative mps .	in the range between 1980 and 1990 , what did demand for grow ?	in part because the government of the united kingdom was controlled by the conservative party
throughout the 1980s and 1990s , demand for a scottish parliament grew , in part because the government of the united kingdom was controlled by the conservative party , while scotland itself elected relatively few conservative mps .	whose control of the uk 's government helped fuel a desire for a scottish parliament ?	in part because the government of the united kingdom was controlled by the conservative party
in the aftermath of the 1979 referendum defeat , the campaign for a scottish assembly was initiated as a pressure group , leading to the 1989 scottish constitutional convention with various organisations such as scottish churches , political parties and representatives of industry taking part .	when was the scottish constitutional convention held ?	leading to the 1989 scottish constitutional convention with various organisations such as scottish churches
publishing its blueprint for devolution in 1995 , the convention provided much of the basis for the structure of the parliament .	what provided much of the basis for the structure of the parliament in 1995 ?	the convention provided much of the basis for the structure of the parliament
since september 2004 , the official home of the scottish parliament has been a new scottish parliament building , in the holyrood area of edinburgh .	where has the official home of the scottish parliament been since 2004 ?	the official home of the scottish parliament has been a new scottish parliament building
the scottish parliament building was designed by spanish architect enric miralles in partnership with local edinburgh architecture firm rmjm which was led by design principal tony kettle .	who designed the scottish parliament building ?	the scottish parliament building was designed by spanish architect enric miralles in partnership with local edinburgh architecture firm rmjm which was led by design principal tony kettle
the scottish parliament building was designed by spanish architect enric miralles in partnership with local edinburgh architecture firm rmjm which was led by design principal tony kettle .	what nationality is the architect enric miralles ?	the scottish parliament building was designed by spanish architect enric miralles in partnership with local edinburgh architecture firm rmjm which was led by design principal tony kettle
some of the principal features of the complex include leaf-shaped buildings , a grass-roofed branch merging into adjacent parkland and gabion walls formed from the stones of previous buildings .	what shape are some of the buildings in the parliament complex ?	a grass-roofed branch merging into adjacent parkland and gabion walls formed from the stones of previous buildings
queen elizabeth ii opened the new building on 9 october 2004 .	who opened the new parliament building on october 9 , 2004 ?	queen elizabeth ii opened the new building on 9 october 2004
this building was vacated twice to allow for the meeting of the church 's general assembly .	what was the building vacated twice to allow for ?	this building was vacated twice to allow for the meeting of the church 's general assembly
whilst the permanent building at holyrood was being constructed , the parliament 's temporary home was the general assembly hall of the church of scotland on the royal mile in edinburgh .	where was parliament 's temporary home whilst the permanent building was being built ?	the parliament 's temporary home was the general assembly hall of the church of scotland on the royal mile in edinburgh
official photographs and television interviews were held in the courtyard adjoining the assembly hall , which is part of the school of divinity of the university of edinburgh .	where were interviews held while the parliament was in its temporary building ?	official photographs and television interviews were held in the courtyard adjoining the assembly hall
in may 2000 , the parliament was temporarily relocated to the former strathclyde regional council debating chamber in glasgow , and to the university of aberdeen in may 2002 .	in may 2002 , where would you go to address the parliament ?	the parliament was temporarily relocated to the former strathclyde regional council debating chamber in glasgow
in may 2000 , the parliament was temporarily relocated to the former strathclyde regional council debating chamber in glasgow , and to the university of aberdeen in may 2002 .	where was parliament temporarily relocated to in may of 2000 ?	the parliament was temporarily relocated to the former strathclyde regional council debating chamber in glasgow
in addition to the general assembly hall , the parliament also used buildings rented from the city of edinburgh council .	who did the parliament rent additional buildings from ?	the parliament also used buildings rented from the city of edinburgh council
the former administrative building of lothian regional council on george iv bridge was used for the msp 's offices .	what former administrative building was used for the msp 's offices ?	the former administrative building of lothian regional council on george iv bridge was used for the msp 's offices
following the move to holyrood in 2004 this building was demolished .	what happened to the building on george iv bridge when the parliament was done with it ?	following the move to holyrood in 2004 this building was demolished
the former midlothian county buildings facing parliament square , high street and george iv bridge in edinburgh -lrb- originally built as the headquarters of the pre-1975 midlothian county council -rrb- housed the parliament 's visitors ' centre and shop , whilst the main hall was used as the parliament 's principal committee room .	what do the former midlothian county buildings face ?	high street and george iv bridge in edinburgh -lrb- originally built as the headquarters of the pre-1975 midlothian county council -rrb- housed the parliament 's visitors ' centre and shop

after each election to the scottish parliament , at the beginning of each parliamentary session , parliament elects one msp to serve as presiding officer , the equivalent of the speaker -lrb- currently tricia marwick -rrb- , and two msps to serve as deputies -lrb- currently elaine smith and john scott -rrb- .	who is elected to serve as the presiding officer at the beginning of each parliamentary session ?	and two msps to serve as deputies -lrb- currently elaine smith and john scott -rrb-
after each election to the scottish parliament , at the beginning of each parliamentary session , parliament elects one msp to serve as presiding officer , the equivalent of the speaker -lrb- currently tricia marwick -rrb- , and two msps to serve as deputies -lrb- currently elaine smith and john scott -rrb- .	who is currently speaker of the scottish parliament ?	and two msps to serve as deputies -lrb- currently elaine smith and john scott -rrb-
the presiding officer and deputies are elected by a secret ballot of the 129 msps , which is the only secret ballot conducted in the scottish parliament .	what type of ballot is used to elect the presiding officer and deputies of the parliament ?	the presiding officer and deputies are elected by a secret ballot of the 129 msps
the presiding officer and deputies are elected by a secret ballot of the 129 msps , which is the only secret ballot conducted in the scottish parliament .	how many msps are there ?	the presiding officer and deputies are elected by a secret ballot of the 129 msps
a vote clerk sits in front of the presiding officer and operates the electronic voting equipment and chamber clocks .	who is responsible for operating the electronic voting equipment and chamber clocks ?	a vote clerk sits in front of the presiding officer and operates the electronic voting equipment and chamber clocks
as a member of the scottish parliamentary corporate body , the presiding officer is responsible for ensuring that the parliament functions effectively and has the staff , property and resources it requires to operate .	who is responsible for ensuring the parliament works smoothly ?	the presiding officer is responsible for ensuring that the parliament functions effectively and has the staff
convening the parliamentary bureau , which allocates time and sets the work agenda in the chamber , is another of the roles of the presiding officer .	who sets the work agenda and allocates time in the chamber ?	which allocates time and sets the work agenda in the chamber
under the standing orders of the parliament the bureau consists of the presiding officer and one representative from each political parties with five or more seats in the parliament .	how many seats must a political party have to be represented on the parliamentary bureau ?	under the standing orders of the parliament the bureau consists of the presiding officer and one representative from each political parties with five or more seats in the parliament
the presiding officer also represents the scottish parliament at home and abroad in an official capacity .	who represents the scottish parliament at home and abroad in an official capacity ?	the presiding officer also represents the scottish parliament at home and abroad in an official capacity
the debating chamber of the scottish parliament has seating arranged in a hemicycle , which reflects the desire to encourage consensus amongst elected members .	what is the seating arrangement of the debating chamber ?	the debating chamber of the scottish parliament has seating arranged in a hemicycle
the debating chamber of the scottish parliament has seating arranged in a hemicycle , which reflects the desire to encourage consensus amongst elected members .	why is the seating of the debating chamber arranged as it is ?	the debating chamber of the scottish parliament has seating arranged in a hemicycle
there are 131 seats in the debating chamber .	how many seats are in the debating chamber ?	there are 131 seats in the debating chamber
of the total 131 seats , 129 are occupied by the parliament 's elected msps and 2 are seats for the scottish law officers -- the lord advocate and the solicitor general for scotland , who are not elected members of the parliament but are members of the scottish government .	how many members in the seats of the scottish parliament are members of the scottish government ?	129 are occupied by the parliament 's elected msps and 2 are seats for the scottish law officers -- the lord advocate and the solicitor general for scotland
as such the law officers may attend and speak in the plenary meetings of the parliament but , as they are not elected msps , can not vote .	what can the non-elected members from the scottish government not do ?	as such the law officers may attend and speak in the plenary meetings of the parliament but
in front of the presiding officers ' desk is the parliamentary mace , which is made from silver and inlaid with gold panned from scottish rivers and inscribed with the words : wisdom , compassion , justice and integrity .	where does the gold in the parliamentary mace come from ?	which is made from silver and inlaid with gold panned from scottish rivers and inscribed with the words : wisdom
in front of the presiding officers ' desk is the parliamentary mace , which is made from silver and inlaid with gold panned from scottish rivers and inscribed with the words : wisdom , compassion , justice and integrity .	what is the parliamentary mace made of ?	which is made from silver and inlaid with gold panned from scottish rivers and inscribed with the words : wisdom
presented to the scottish parliament by the queen upon its official opening in july 1999 , the mace is displayed in a glass case suspended from the lid .	who presented the mac to the scottish parliament when it was initially opened ?	presented to the scottish parliament by the queen upon its official opening in july 1999
in front of the presiding officers ' desk is the parliamentary mace , which is made from silver and inlaid with gold panned from scottish rivers and inscribed with the words : wisdom , compassion , justice and integrity .	what words are inscribed on the mace of parliament ?	which is made from silver and inlaid with gold panned from scottish rivers and inscribed with the words : wisdom

parliament typically sits tuesdays , wednesdays and thursdays from early january to late june and from early september to mid december , with two-week recesses in april and october .	which month is the first in the year parliament takes a two week vacation ?	wednesdays and thursdays from early january to late june and from early september to mid december
plenary meetings in the debating chamber usually take place on wednesday afternoons from 2 pm to 6 pm and on thursdays from 9:15 am to 6 pm .	where do plenary meetings take place ?	plenary meetings in the debating chamber usually take place on wednesday afternoons from 2 pm to 6 pm and on thursdays from 9:15 am to 6 pm
chamber debates and committee meetings are open to the public .	who are debates and meetings open to ?	chamber debates and committee meetings are open to the public
entry is free , but booking in advance is recommended due to limited space .	how much does it cost to gain entry to a parliament meeting ?	but booking in advance is recommended due to limited space
proceedings are also recorded in text form , in print and online , in the official report , which is the substantially verbatim transcript of parliamentary debates .	what contains a nearly verbatim of parliamentary debates ?	which is the substantially verbatim transcript of parliamentary debates
the first item of business on wednesdays is usually time for reflection , at which a speaker addresses members for up to four minutes , sharing a perspective on issues of faith .	what day of the week does the time for reflection take place ?	the first item of business on wednesdays is usually time for reflection
the first item of business on wednesdays is usually time for reflection , at which a speaker addresses members for up to four minutes , sharing a perspective on issues of faith .	how long might a speaker address the members during the time of reflection ?	the first item of business on wednesdays is usually time for reflection
invitations to address parliament in this manner are determined by the presiding officer on the advice of the parliamentary bureau .	who decides who gets to address the members of parliament to share their thoughts on issues of faith ?	invitations to address parliament in this manner are determined by the presiding officer on the advice of the parliamentary bureau
speakers are drawn from across scotland and are chosen to represent the balance of religious beliefs according to the scottish census .	because speakers are drawn from across scotland , what do the represent the balance of ?	speakers are drawn from across scotland and are chosen to represent the balance of religious beliefs according to the scottish census
faith groups can make direct representations to the presiding officer to nominate speakers .	what can faith groups ask the presiding officer to do for them ?	faith groups can make direct representations to the presiding officer to nominate speakers
the presiding officer -lrb- or deputy presiding officer -rrb- decides who speaks in chamber debates and the amount of time for which they are allowed to speak .	who decides who gets to speak in the chamber debates ?	the presiding officer -lrb- or deputy presiding officer -rrb- decides who speaks in chamber debates and the amount of time for which they are allowed to speak

normally , the presiding officer tries to achieve a balance between different viewpoints and political parties when selecting members to speak .	what does the presiding officer try to achieve a balance of between speakers ?	the presiding officer tries to achieve a balance between different viewpoints and political parties when selecting members to speak
typically , ministers or party leaders open debates , with opening speakers given between 5 and 20 minutes , and succeeding speakers allocated less time .	what members typically open debates ?	with opening speakers given between 5 and 20 minutes
the scottish parliament has conducted debates in the gaelic language .	what language other than english has the scottish parliament had meetings in ?	the scottish parliament has conducted debates in the gaelic language
each sitting day , normally at 5 pm , msps decide on all the motions and amendments that have been moved that day .	what time do the msps normally decide on the motions and amendments from that day ?	msps decide on all the motions and amendments that have been moved that day
this `` decision time '' is heralded by the sounding of the division bell , which is heard throughout the parliamentary campus and alerts msps who are not in the chamber to return and vote .	what is heralded by the sounding of the division bell ?	which is heard throughout the parliamentary campus and alerts msps who are not in the chamber to return and vote
this `` decision time '' is heralded by the sounding of the division bell , which is heard throughout the parliamentary campus and alerts msps who are not in the chamber to return and vote .	what do msps who are not in the chamber when the division bell rings return to do ?	which is heard throughout the parliamentary campus and alerts msps who are not in the chamber to return and vote
if there is audible dissent , the presiding officer announces `` there will be a division '' and members vote by means of electronic consoles on their desks .	how do members vote when there is a division ?	the presiding officer announces `` there will be a division '' and members vote by means of electronic consoles on their desks
as a result , the outcome of each division is known in seconds .	how long does it take to know the outcome of a division ?	the outcome of each division is known in seconds
the outcome of most votes can be predicted beforehand since political parties normally instruct members which way to vote .	what can often be predicted beforehand ?	the outcome of most votes can be predicted beforehand since political parties normally instruct members which way to vote
the outcome of most votes can be predicted beforehand since political parties normally instruct members which way to vote .	who normally instructs members how to vote ?	the outcome of most votes can be predicted beforehand since political parties normally instruct members which way to vote
parties entrust some msps , known as whips , with the task of ensuring that party members vote according to the party line .	who has the task of ensuring party members vote according to the party line ?	with the task of ensuring that party members vote according to the party line
this is typically done on moral issues .	what type of issues are members typically allowed to vote as they please ?	this is typically done on moral issues
errant members can be deselected as official party candidates during future elections , and , in serious cases , may be expelled from their parties outright .	what happens if a member does n't vote the party line ?	errant members can be deselected as official party candidates during future elections
immediately after decision time a `` members debate '' is held , which lasts for 45 minutes .	when is the members debate held ?	immediately after decision time a `` members debate '' is held
members business is a debate on a motion proposed by an msp who is not a scottish minister .	why are debates on proposed motions by an msp conducted ?	members business is a debate on a motion proposed by an msp who is not a scottish minister
immediately after decision time a `` members debate '' is held , which lasts for 45 minutes .	how long does the members debate last ?	immediately after decision time a `` members debate '' is held
as well as the proposer , other members normally contribute to the debate .	who contributes to members business in addition to the proposer ?	other members normally contribute to the debate
the relevant minister , whose department the debate and motion relate to `` winds up '' the debate by speaking after all other participants .	what does the minister who was the catalyst of the members business do by speaking after everyone else ?	whose department the debate and motion relate to `` winds up '' the debate by speaking after all other participants
much of the work of the scottish parliament is done in committee .	where is much of the work of the scottish parliament done ?	much of the work of the scottish parliament is done in committee
the role of committees is stronger in the scottish parliament than in other parliamentary systems , partly as a means of strengthening the role of backbenchers in their scrutiny of the government and partly to compensate for the fact that there is no revising chamber .	what are committees in the scottish parliament compared to other systems ?	partly as a means of strengthening the role of backbenchers in their scrutiny of the government and partly to compensate for the fact that there is no revising chamber
the role of committees is stronger in the scottish parliament than in other parliamentary systems , partly as a means of strengthening the role of backbenchers in their scrutiny of the government and partly to compensate for the fact that there is no revising chamber .	what is one avenue being compensated for by having committees serve such a large role ?	partly as a means of strengthening the role of backbenchers in their scrutiny of the government and partly to compensate for the fact that there is no revising chamber
the principal role of committees in the scottish parliament is to take evidence from witnesses , conduct inquiries and scrutinise legislation .	taking evidence from witnesses is one of committees ' what ?	the principal role of committees in the scottish parliament is to take evidence from witnesses
committees can also meet at other locations throughout scotland .	where might committees meet outside of parliament ?	committees can also meet at other locations throughout scotland
committees comprise a small number of msps , with membership reflecting the balance of parties across parliament .	who are committees comprised of ?	with membership reflecting the balance of parties across parliament
committees comprise a small number of msps , with membership reflecting the balance of parties across parliament .	what do the membership of the committees reflect ?	with membership reflecting the balance of parties across parliament
there are different committees with their functions set out in different ways .	different committees have what set out in different ways ?	there are different committees with their functions set out in different ways
mandatory committees are committees which are set down under the scottish parliament 's standing orders , which govern their remits and proceedings .	what type of committee is set down under the sp 's standing orders ?	mandatory committees are committees which are set down under the scottish parliament 's standing orders
the current mandatory committees in the fourth session of the scottish parliament are : public audit ; equal opportunities ; european and external relations ; finance ; public petitions ; standards , procedures and public appointments ; and delegated powers and law reform .	what session is the scottish parliament in ?	the current mandatory committees in the fourth session of the scottish parliament are : public audit
subject committees are established at the beginning of each parliamentary session , and again the members on each committee reflect the balance of parties across parliament .	when are subject committees established ?	and again the members on each committee reflect the balance of parties across parliament
typically each committee corresponds with one -lrb- or more -rrb- of the departments -lrb- or ministries -rrb- of the scottish government .	how many ministries of the scottish government does a committee typically correspond to ?	typically each committee corresponds with one -lrb- or more -rrb- of the departments -lrb- or ministries -rrb- of the scottish government
the current subject committees in the fourth session are : economy , energy and tourism ; education and culture ; health and sport ; justice ; local government and regeneration ; rural affairs , climate change and environment ; welfare reform ; and infrastructure and capital investment .	economy , energy and tourism is one of the what ?	the current subject committees in the fourth session are : economy
the current subject committees in the fourth session are : economy , energy and tourism ; education and culture ; health and sport ; justice ; local government and regeneration ; rural affairs , climate change and environment ; welfare reform ; and infrastructure and capital investment .	what is the scottish parliament currently in the fourth of ?	the current subject committees in the fourth session are : economy
a further type of committee is normally set up to scrutinise private bills submitted to the scottish parliament by an outside party or promoter who is not a member of the scottish parliament or scottish government .	what is set up to scrutinize private bills submitted by party outsiders ?	a further type of committee is normally set up to scrutinise private bills submitted to the scottish parliament by an outside party or promoter who is not a member of the scottish parliament or scottish government
private bills normally relate to large-scale development projects such as infrastructure projects that require the use of land or property .	what topic do private bills typically have ?	private bills normally relate to large-scale development projects such as infrastructure projects that require the use of land or property

private bill committees have been set up to consider legislation on issues such as the development of the edinburgh tram network , the glasgow airport rail link , the airdrie-bathgate rail link and extensions to the national gallery of scotland .	what kind of committee considered legislation on the development of the edinburgh tram network ?	private bill committees have been set up to consider legislation on issues such as the development of the edinburgh tram network
the scotland act 1998 , which was passed by the parliament of the united kingdom and given royal assent by queen elizabeth ii on 19 november 1998 , governs the functions and role of the scottish parliament and delimits its legislative competence .	what act sets forth the functions of the scottish parliament ?	which was passed by the parliament of the united kingdom and given royal assent by queen elizabeth ii on 19 november 1998

the scotland act 2012 extends the devolved competencies .	what does the scotland act of 2012 extend ?	the scotland act 2012 extends the devolved competencies
for the purposes of parliamentary sovereignty , the parliament of the united kingdom at westminster continues to constitute the supreme legislature of scotland .	what body constitutes the supreme legislature of scotland ?	the parliament of the united kingdom at westminster continues to constitute the supreme legislature of scotland
the scottish parliament has the power to pass laws and has limited tax-varying capability .	who has the role of holding the scottish government to account ?	the scottish parliament has the power to pass laws and has limited tax-varying capability
the specific devolved matters are all subjects which are not explicitly stated in schedule 5 to the scotland act as reserved matters .	where are reserved matters stated in the scotland act ?	the specific devolved matters are all subjects which are not explicitly stated in schedule 5 to the scotland act as reserved matters
all matters that are not specifically reserved are automatically devolved to the scottish parliament .	if a matter is not specifically reserved , who is it devolved to ?	all matters that are not specifically reserved are automatically devolved to the scottish parliament

the 2012 act conferred further fiscal devolution including borrowing powers and some other unconnected matters such as setting speed limits and control of air guns .	setting speed limits was one of the further devolutions which was conferred by what act ?	the 2012 act conferred further fiscal devolution including borrowing powers and some other unconnected matters such as setting speed limits and control of air guns
reserved matters are subjects that are outside the legislative competence of the scotland parliament .	what is the name of matters outside the legislative ability of the scottish parliament ?	reserved matters are subjects that are outside the legislative competence of the scotland parliament
